number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												Guacamelee is the latest competitor to enter the 'Metroidvania' wrestling ring (see what I did there?)... har har. Ahem. So it is a worthy descendant of the classics? In a word, yes. There's a lot to like about this one. First of all, the Mexican style/setting is something I can't recall ever seeing in a game before, and it actually works really well. The characters are cool and the writing is decent. Secondly, the combat is surprisingly deep and can be challenging at times. You play as a luchador and mainly utilize wrestling moves to take down your opponents. After beating on a guy for a bit, you get the option to grapple and toss them. This ends up being really fun, especially when you start racking up huge combos by throwing dudes into a group of other dudes. It's not simply a mindless beat-'em-up, though. There is a deeper layer of strategy and skill required, as certain enemies can only be defeated with careful timing or by using specific special moves to break their defenses first. It's not too hard versus 1 or 2 enemies, but when the game throws a screen full of baddies at you with projectiles flying all over the place, it can actually get a bit challenging. Aside from combat, the game also mixes in some classic 2D platforming. Some of these sections will really put your skills to the test, as they require precise coordination of various moves to be strung together very quickly. This could have potentially been very frustrating, but luckily, the game is very forgiving when it comes to the platforming. If you fall to your "death", you just end up back on the most recent platform you touched with no other penalty. While this may seem dumbed down, you'll be glad for it... trust me. Overall, the game does a great job of tuning the balance of difficulty between its various systems. The toughest parts are probably the boss fights, which require patience, observation and exploitation of patterns. You'll be challenged, but with a bit of practice, you'll eventually get by. Depending on how quickly you play or how completionist you want to get, the game will last you anywhere from 9-13 hours, and many more if you plan to go for the best ending or complete all of the challenges in the "El Infierno" DLC level (included for free). So it's a good value for the money (and I haven't even touched at all on how many gaming references and other neat touches can be found throughout). Guacamelee is a serious love-fest for gaming fans and especially those who love the Metroidvania sub-genre. If that sounds like you, then pick this one up without hesitation.Technical notes: I know I say this for almost every sidescroller, but seriously, I mean it this time - you are gonna want to use a gamepad for this one (specifically an Xbox360 controller if you have one). I suppose it's possible to play this with a keyboard, but I sure as hell wouldn't want to. Some of the platforming and combat sections need split-second finesse maneuvering, which is hard enough even with a controller. The developers even put up a note at the start of the game that they recommend using a controller. Whenever I see those warnings in a game from a developer, I have learned to heed them. You probably should too. So think twice about buying this if you don't have a gamepad with the standard layout of buttons/sticks.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												TL;DR I closet love this game. The music is great, the gameplay is solid, and it is intentionally silly. Not only that, but it's also got a really fun combat system and it actually forces you to learn how to play the game so that, by the end, you know what you're doing; it's not like other games where you can more or less wing what you're doing and just follow the objective marker to get to the end. I'd give this game something like an 8.5/10 or so. Not quite as high as a 9 or 10, but also slightly ahead of most 8s.Guacamelee is a game where you play as some Mexican guy to avenge the girl he closet loves after being smashed by the guy who stole her away from the village. You do this by dawning the a mask that has the soul of a former luchador or something. Look, listen, I don't care for story, I like gameplay, visuals, and sounds.Guacamelee is a beat-em-up influenced by Mexican culture. Simple premise. You, as a luchador, can learn grabs, throws, combos, and other things to help you get though the legions of baddies sent to delay you from getting to the final boss. Not all baddies can be dispatched the same way, though. Some require you to break their shield by performing a special super move (using your meter), some require throws, and some just need some knuckles to the dome. Perfect. Exactly what you'd expect from a beat-em-up.But wait, that's not all of the gameplay. There's also some platforming. What? Platforming? Yeah, I know, listen: each of the special moves that you learn influence your character's movement. The TOTALLY NOT SHORYUKEN moves your character up so you can get some vertical movement, there's a belly flop that moves you down to the lowest platform (or breaks blocks that can be broken), and there's a dash that moves you sideways...  Look, listen, basically you're forced to use the moves you learn not only in combat, but also to get around. It's pretty neat. There's also this concept of the netherworld or whatever that is merging with the human world, so, sometimes, things change to reflect how they are in the other dimension. This becomes something that you can control and offers some interesting puzzle-platforming like things where you have to pusha da button real fast and stuff to get to another area. The game also rewards you for going back to revisit places and stuff, so that's cool. Always gotta give shout outs to games that reward players for going back and experimenting with newfound powers.That's really all there is to the gameplay. It's not terribly difficult to learn, and getting the combos off from the chicken's gym will be pretty satisfying because some of them are lengthy for a beat-em-up. Everyone that plays fighting games knows the satisfaction from getting off a lengthy combo. What else is there to talk about after the gameplay? Oh yeah, visuals. This game is 2d and feels like how Samurai Jack would be if it were a video game. 2d with not too many circles. A lot of things are obviously overdone. It's not a bad thing by any means. That said, I wasn't too impressed with it. Beyond the simple graphics, though, the game has a ton of references to internet stuff in the background. One thing that makes me love games is being silly and this game is totally silly. It doesn't detract from gameplay and isn't in-your-face narration from a character you don't care about, but it's mostly harmless jokes or references to things. Then there's the music. Ok, look, listen, I'm Mexican and I grew up listening to some pretty ethnic music. Most of it I didn't really care for, but this game took all the good parts of the music I didn't like and smashed it together to form a REALLY REALLY solid soundtrack. Like, holy crap, I actually listen to some of the songs from this game regularly because they sound so nice. You'll get some pretty stereotypical accordion and brass instruments playing, but you'll also, for example, in the jungle area, get some fast drums because fast drums are associated with jungles because reasons. Yeah, but what's not to like about this game? It offers solid beat-em-up gameplay, neat platforming, and even some puzzles. The graphics aren't anything highest-end, but they get the job done and look just dandy anyway. The game doesn't take itself too seriously and this game is just genuinely fun to play. It also has a fantastic soundtrack. I'd highly adivse anyone to pick up this game. Also, this game tends to be on sale pretty often, so there's almost no reason to pick it up if you don't already own it and it's on sale. I personally got mine off a humble bundle and it was great. One thing I would have really liked was if this game had online multiplayer or something, but it doesn't, and that's I guess permissable. It offers local co-op, so I guess that'll have to suffice.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I love metroidvania games, ever since I first played an import copy of Symphony of the Night way back when, and I've played every Castlevania or other major title in the genre since. I don't think I'm exaggerating when I say that Guacamelee is one of the very best games the genre has ever seen.The game really has everything; excellent graphics with a healthy serving of style, wonderful music, tight and well-executed controls and combat and a world that's simply fun to explore. That's really the key word here; this game is FUN! Everything from juggling enemies and racking up a 300 hit combo to exploring every nook and cranny of the world is constantly and consistently engaging and entertaining. The game also keeps things fresh by throwing a curveball or two your way, mostly in the shape of balls-hard platforming segments, almost on the level of something like Super Meat Boy. This is actually something I think the game does well, because most entries in this genre have pretty uninteresting and frankly lame platforming, Castlevania included. Guacamelee wears its platform roots on its sleeve and demands some tricky, technical jumping from you, and it's all the better for it.As you can see, I have nothing but praise for this game. I could ramble on about how much I love it all day, so I'm just going to summarize and say that if you have any interest in this genre and haven't played this game yet, you absolutely have to. Like right now. Do not pass go, do not wait for a sale; play it immediately!

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Guacamelee is an enjoyable action platformer, in which you'll play as a Wrestler on a Quest to save a girl and yeah that sounds like Mario - This game likes to reference a lot of different games, but also some real life stuff, I found it very satisfying to find eater eggs in this game.Although this game doesn't have a perfect pacing, due to one point in the game, where the plattforming starts to get really complicating and you suddenly have to use a lot more abilities at the same time, which gets you likely stuck on a quarter of a level about an hour or two, it's annoying, but at the same time the only real negative point about the game.Gameplay wise is the game divided into plattforming and brawler-like combat. What makes the plattforming really interesting is that you can use your wrestling moves you'll learn over the course of the game, to reach your destination. In combat you use as already mentioned wrestling moves to defeat your enemies, apart from that you can throw a damaged enemy, who can be thrown onto other enemies, which is not only efficient, but is very satisfying to do.Even though you are very limited with the throwing when using a keyboard. Because I still don't have a controller I used a keyboard for this game and personally I found that the keyboard controls difficult to get used to, but didn't feel at a disadvantage because of the limited throwing. Apart from that the PC-Port seems fine.Overall I didn't see any major flaws with the game, it was just challenging enough, it doesn't have a perfect pacing, but cool Easter eggs, I'll recommend to people, who are looking for a challenging platformer and like to find references/Easter eggs.

												Guacamelee is an under-rated gem! It is a fantastic side-scrolling metroidvania style game set in a Mexican luchador themed world. I highly recommended playing it if you're looking for a fun coop game to play. It's stylish, comical, and has a great soundtrack, and although it can be fiendishly difficult in parts it doesn’t penalise you for dying (which you will do ALOT of!). For such a simple game there is quite a large array of special moves, which once mastered allows you to backtrack over previous levels and unlock hidden areas and challenges. The 'Gold Edition' also features an extra level of challenges which definitely increases the replayablity value. Because of the accuracy needed to succeed, I would personally recommend playing this game with a controller, rather than keyboard/mouse.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Where do I even start on this? Guacamelee is a metroidvania-style action-platformer based on luchadores and different bits of Mexican culture. It's stylish, funny, and fun. For the most part the game is just a great romp where you beat up bad guys in awesome combos and explore new areas, getting new powers and abilities as you go. The difficulty curve is... mostly okay, though there are a few spikes of really really frustrating platforming at times. Some of these spikes are optional, but some of them are mandatory. The story isn't deep, but it is fun and the characters are all nifty as well. Overall, pretty damned solid game and one that I recommend despite a few blemishes.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I'm going to feel like such a nitpicky jerk talking about this game's flaws, because everything else is just really good. But we'll get to them.Guacamelee! is a muscular Metroidvania, a world where the mask is a very literal symbol of strength and the powerups are sealed behind openings that only ancient body-press techniques will open. Its world is a bit more linear then some Metroidvania-inspired titles, but there's still a pretty solid amount of nooks and crannies to break open and revisit with new tricks. Just about all of your movement or "unlocking" abilities are combat-oriented-the blue doors are unlocking by dash-punching, for instance, giving you regular new tricks in fights. Things that don't move you tend to move enemies, so you're almost always able to keep a combo going, either by reaching someone or hurling someone into a distant group. The fights are fast and fluid, and a little bit of dimension-changing thrown in offers a manageable issue that'll still keep you on your toes.The platforming's fine, too-just as some enemies only exist in one of the dimensions, so do some blocks and walls, making you keep switching to get past things, have safe landing points, etc. When it flows, it's a real joy to bounce around the game.Problem #1 is that it doesn't always flow, though. Hazards (spikes, nasty water, thorns, etc.) tend to have a pretty big hitbox, and even nearly-but-not-quite grazing something can send you spiraling to the ground below-this is a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥on vertical segments, especially since there's no safe-fall. Thankfully, these are few and far between. Still, though, landing in water or falling off into a pit teleports you to solid ground, immediately-it's actually worse to land on a platform below where you were. A strange choice.Problem #2 is that our hero, Juan, presumably a técnico, has a pile driver move. He really shouldn't-that's for rudos.Those are nitpicks, though. Overall, the game's just fantastic. If you need a sidescroller, this thing deserves a place in your library.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												This game does a lot of things well. It has a very unique dual world warping mechanic that is used throughout the entire game, is very intuitive, and meshes well with the other game mechanics and storyline. Unfortunately, it deceives you with one game and replaces it with another. The sound, art style, combat mechanics, and metroidvania ability mechanics are all very well designed, but it also has many flaws. Most important flaw is the use of color-coded puzzles and combat mechanics without a colorblind-friendly mode. This makes the already difficult combat a dice roll for the colorblind.The game starts off as a very good beat-em-up metroidvania, but at the end it becomes an extremely hard (super meat boy level hard, no exageration) platformer with a few combat sequences in between. Though a lot of the very hard platforming is optional, they are very unforgiving and require godly levels of coordination with very very sparse checkpoints.The combat at later stages also border on unfair levels of difficulty. Enemies can exist in another world that you can't hurt, but they can hurt you. A lot of later enemies also have unblockable attacks, so you end up with half the screen full of enemies you can't hit or block.  You have to swap worlds to deal with these two types of world enemies, and they can overlap each other and not hit or shoot one another. Getting hit is also a major punishment as you are knocked out for a fair amount of time. The worse thing, though is being knocked far away from your enemies. Being a melee only character, not being able to get close to enemies who are charging for unblockable attacks is bad. The hit stun is way too long and punishing when there are large numbers of these enemies. Although it's rare, it is also possible to be stunlocked in some arenas that have a large number of enemies. The DLC shows you just what the developers had in mind for this game as they are all platforming based with little to no combat. This is a puzzle platformer disguised as a combat metroidvania. If you like supermeatboy type platformers with very difficult combat, then this game is for you. For anyone like me expecting metroid or castlevania style gameplay, you probably won't find this game very fun after the first half.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												I wanted to recommend this game because it has style and attitude and charm galore...But...There are too-many aspects of it which are amateurish and they mar the game to an ever-greater degree as you progress.We're talking about things like unstoppable player/enemy animations which interfere with combat/movement, slow-to-respond controls (probably due to the aforesaid animations), areas you have to repeat if you make a mistake and lazy/buggy AI behavior ExampleYou can't always thread-together combat moves because every move has an animation and you have to wait to wait for those to take place.  Thing is - you have to do this VISUALLY in a game where you/the enemies often obscure each-other - this isn't a brililant idea...Other issues appear in terms of what simply badly tested/lazy scripting/designExampleYou can hit an enemy, they'll fly away and then the missile they were about  to throw will appear where they were standing anyway (likely hitting you).  You'll also hear the sound of an enemy's move  DESPITE the fact you should stunned or killed it and thus stopped the move from taking place!?Maybe you can tolerate those things for a while - I did - but sooner or later you will realise the game is really "working against you". ANDBefore you buy, ensure you have a joystick/pad with a decent DPad.  Playing this on keyboard is impossible and the a 360 pad left stick isn't precise enough/DPad is a joke.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												The first time I tried playing through this game, I gave up for almost 2 years. I wasn't quite sure why. I recently retried, because this is a good game and I didn't understand why I disliked it. I did figure out why, though, as I got to a certain mechanic that turned every platforming incident into a timing and reaction dependent stress-fest with massive consequences for failure. Didn't help that the fighting gets progressively sloppier as you get more combos. I happen to not like combos. Also for some reason, the grappling speeds up as you progress. This makes it harder to do the grappling combos, even though they're simple as hell.Ultimately, I didn't like the combo based fighting and the platforming turned into an unduly frustrating experience. I think it's actually a good game, still, but I don't like it and I won't recommend it as such. If you like combos and super meat boy platforming, go for it.

												Let's just shove as many forced memes and as much internet lingo into a game as we can, make combat a bunch of button mashing (with no penalty instant respawns upon death), sprinkle in some boring dialogue for literally every character, and top it all off with a very pointlessly executed light and dark world system.  Add a side of simple but not unique visuals, and serve lukewarm.Target audience: Reddit.  I think i counted the word "awesomesauce" at least 4 times now, along with oh... 12 epic maymay pictures ranging from GENTLEMEN to grumpy cat.  Stylized, of course.  Oh, can't forget the references like when you kill a dragon thing Super Mario Bros. style (cutting the bridge over lava with a golden axe thing) and the villain says "your princess is in another castle".Eh, it's kinda fun.  The in-level music is probably the best part out of everything (and probably the most original content...).

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												The first time I tried playing through this game, I gave up for almost 2 years. I wasn't quite sure why. I recently retried, because this is a good game and I didn't understand why I disliked it. I did figure out why, though, as I got to a certain mechanic that turned every platforming incident into a timing and reaction dependent stress-fest with massive consequences for failure. Didn't help that the fighting gets progressively sloppier as you get more combos. I happen to not like combos. Also for some reason, the grappling speeds up as you progress. This makes it harder to do the grappling combos, even though they're simple as hell.Ultimately, I didn't like the combo based fighting and the platforming turned into an unduly frustrating experience. I think it's actually a good game, still, but I don't like it and I won't recommend it as such. If you like combos and super meat boy platforming, go for it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												This game does a lot of things well. It has a very unique dual world warping mechanic that is used throughout the entire game, is very intuitive, and meshes well with the other game mechanics and storyline. Unfortunately, it deceives you with one game and replaces it with another. The sound, art style, combat mechanics, and metroidvania ability mechanics are all very well designed, but it also has many flaws. Most important flaw is the use of color-coded puzzles and combat mechanics without a colorblind-friendly mode. This makes the already difficult combat a dice roll for the colorblind.The game starts off as a very good beat-em-up metroidvania, but at the end it becomes an extremely hard (super meat boy level hard, no exageration) platformer with a few combat sequences in between. Though a lot of the very hard platforming is optional, they are very unforgiving and require godly levels of coordination with very very sparse checkpoints.The combat at later stages also border on unfair levels of difficulty. Enemies can exist in another world that you can't hurt, but they can hurt you. A lot of later enemies also have unblockable attacks, so you end up with half the screen full of enemies you can't hit or block.  You have to swap worlds to deal with these two types of world enemies, and they can overlap each other and not hit or shoot one another. Getting hit is also a major punishment as you are knocked out for a fair amount of time. The worse thing, though is being knocked far away from your enemies. Being a melee only character, not being able to get close to enemies who are charging for unblockable attacks is bad. The hit stun is way too long and punishing when there are large numbers of these enemies. Although it's rare, it is also possible to be stunlocked in some arenas that have a large number of enemies. The DLC shows you just what the developers had in mind for this game as they are all platforming based with little to no combat. This is a puzzle platformer disguised as a combat metroidvania. If you like supermeatboy type platformers with very difficult combat, then this game is for you. For anyone like me expecting metroid or castlevania style gameplay, you probably won't find this game very fun after the first half.

												Even though it shamelessly uses many elements from other games like Metroid or Super Paper Mario, Guacamelee would be a great game if it didn't suffer from unfairness and repetition. Controls are straight, there's lot to discover and the setting reminds me of Grim Fandango, which is obviously a good thing. However not letting me past the first boss even after multiple approaches is a no-go. If the core mechanic of a game consists of prohibiting me playing it, there's something wrong. Regrettable, because the developers showed some real skill.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												While I like the concept, it is an absolutely TERRIBLE console port. The devs "recommend" a controler and cite some flaw with keyboards as the reasons for any problems with the game's controls, but the lack of responsiveness goes beyond acceptable levels. Thousands of other PC games use the mouse and keyboard for controls and most of them manage reasonably smooth gameplay. There is nothing in this game which is so complicated that it would be impossible to make it work with the keyboard, and yet there are some sections which are boarderline unplayable. The problem is that the game is so unresponsive that absolute perfect timing is required to perform even the most basic platforming and combat. This isn't a huge issue when you are fighting one enemy or just hopping up to the next ledge, but there were some sections where I must have spent 20+ minutes trying to complete a jumping puzzle just because the damn Rooster Punch wouldn't work half the time. If you already own a controler, the game seems like it would be pretty good. If you don't, be prepared to spend $8-$30 to be able to play that game you thought was only $7.50.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Guacamelee is a  platformer side scroll - a genre that i really enjoy - here in play the role of Mexican fighter, and he will save his sweetheart, and fight against some weird but fun enemies. Guacamelee is very enjoyable game but is bit hard to play, the combos sometimes don't do well also the controls don't respond on exact time. Also i HIGHLY recommend you play this game with a controller, because with keyboard and mouse you will get a though time. Story is very typical, hero saving the day, rescuing is girl and all bad guys are defeated, but is still fun to play, also this game have a really good jokes between the main charterer and is "mentor". The combat system is the highlight for me, very good very nice combos, also during the story mode you will get new techniques and ability to help during your journey. Best of all, if you have friend in your house at any time he can join you - yes because this game doesn't support online COOP - and help you on your journey. Both OST and scenarios are great, the OST really fits the gameplay in general, Mexican and stuff and scenarios are full of colors and well design. About the replay value on this game, you have two choices: after beating the final boss you can collect the rest of the mask and do the side quests witch are few, about 5/6 or you can try the hard mode, witch can be a good challenge. Well that it, with no doubt Guacamelee deserve every cents that you spend on it. Totally recommend it. ~ 9/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I have never been one for Metroidvania games. That genre has always been too punishing and bland for me. I see the appeal, but for me, it never lasts.Guacamelee is firmly in that genre, and somehow I love it. Maybe it's the prevalence of save points. Maybe it's the fighting system that rewards variety and reflexes instead of perfect aim and conservation of ammo. Maybe it's just the amazing luchadores. I have never played a game in a world of luchadores, and I'm not sure one has ever been made before this.There's a well-told story in a unique setting, an engaging combat system, a high level of difficulty, and a couple hundred in-jokes. There are also tons of secrets to find, dozens of challenges to beat, and a bevy of achievements with varying levels of impossibility. All told, this is a great game for fighter/platformers with a good deal of reward for those who like exploring.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Guacamelee is an under-rated gem! It is a fantastic side-scrolling metroidvania style game set in a Mexican luchador themed world. I highly recommended playing it if you're looking for a fun coop game to play. It's stylish, comical, and has a great soundtrack, and although it can be fiendishly difficult in parts it doesn’t penalise you for dying (which you will do ALOT of!). For such a simple game there is quite a large array of special moves, which once mastered allows you to backtrack over previous levels and unlock hidden areas and challenges. The 'Gold Edition' also features an extra level of challenges which definitely increases the replayablity value. Because of the accuracy needed to succeed, I would personally recommend playing this game with a controller, rather than keyboard/mouse.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I'm going to feel like such a nitpicky jerk talking about this game's flaws, because everything else is just really good. But we'll get to them.Guacamelee! is a muscular Metroidvania, a world where the mask is a very literal symbol of strength and the powerups are sealed behind openings that only ancient body-press techniques will open. Its world is a bit more linear then some Metroidvania-inspired titles, but there's still a pretty solid amount of nooks and crannies to break open and revisit with new tricks. Just about all of your movement or "unlocking" abilities are combat-oriented-the blue doors are unlocking by dash-punching, for instance, giving you regular new tricks in fights. Things that don't move you tend to move enemies, so you're almost always able to keep a combo going, either by reaching someone or hurling someone into a distant group. The fights are fast and fluid, and a little bit of dimension-changing thrown in offers a manageable issue that'll still keep you on your toes.The platforming's fine, too-just as some enemies only exist in one of the dimensions, so do some blocks and walls, making you keep switching to get past things, have safe landing points, etc. When it flows, it's a real joy to bounce around the game.Problem #1 is that it doesn't always flow, though. Hazards (spikes, nasty water, thorns, etc.) tend to have a pretty big hitbox, and even nearly-but-not-quite grazing something can send you spiraling to the ground below-this is a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥on vertical segments, especially since there's no safe-fall. Thankfully, these are few and far between. Still, though, landing in water or falling off into a pit teleports you to solid ground, immediately-it's actually worse to land on a platform below where you were. A strange choice.Problem #2 is that our hero, Juan, presumably a técnico, has a pile driver move. He really shouldn't-that's for rudos.Those are nitpicks, though. Overall, the game's just fantastic. If you need a sidescroller, this thing deserves a place in your library.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Having seen two of my friends finish this game,I thought maybe I had been too harsh in my assessment of the product. Turns out I was right to begin with. The first level is nothing but running back and forth, holding stupid conversations with the locals and jumping up and down while punching some barrels. WOW. Mario has been there and done that already. Then all of a sudden you are dead and there are no clues as to what that giant green sparkly thing in the floor is and can I go back and do something with it? OOPS, no I guess not!  Or why am I being attacked by skeletal Mexicans in ponchos and sombreros and why, why, WHY? I probably have less than an hour in this game and was hoping for more but I found the story to be flat and without real substance and the gameplay to be less than fun (for me, anyway). The colours are nice, and the game appears to be professionally developed but that being said I am glad I only paid $3.00 for this game. Only buy this game if you truly enjoy twitch action side scrolling platformers with repetitive action. Otherwise save your cash. 3/10

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												I wanted to love this game, I really do!The art is great. The music is great. The story is great. Why not everyone love it!?May be this is just me, but I really hate the way you map default controller button, it's the most hardest thing to mastering.- Dashing can be done by both {RS} and {LS}+{LT} ... why?!?- Special move require {B}+{LS} (or sometime, just {B}), this is very troublesome, since {LS} is analog, most of the time the game interprete my action wrong.- Some time you will need to hold down {Y} and then press {A}, such position is not easy to perform at all. I think its too complicate rather than challenging and fun.I also think some achievements are too hard to be done under the game design. For example, Heroine-ism: require Juanita (standard female character) to win final boss fight. This is almost impossible since she can not throw object too far (main attack), and object that she can throw just appear randomly everywhere on the screen, not optimise to appear near the boss. (I know it meant to be hard, but why too hard?) After all, the most importance point is, this achievement state that we need to use a female character to win the game, there are plenty of female characters, but why limited it to be completed with only this standard-lowest-tier female character!?My conclusion is:- For perfectionism who want to complete all achievements, just skip this game, it will made you screaming in F*** word A LOT.- For non-expert platform gamer, just skip, its too hard to completed.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I really want to reccomend this game, it has an authentic sounding soundtrack, charming graphics, references to other video games (Castle Crashers, Team Fortress 2, Super Mario Bros. etc) and casual fun little story. BUT the controls are way too glitchy. The first combo move you learn in the game is Rooster Uppercut which is performed by pressing up and D at the same time. The problem is, the vast majority of the time you press up and D (and I'm not exageratting when I say VAST MAJORITY. It means at least 95% of the time), your character will either jump (up) or do a normal attack (d)This wasn't much of a problem (yes it was) until I learned another combo move, this one is activated with just DNow, whenever I try to Rooster Uppercut, I'll end up doing the new move instead, which takes away a stamina block. Meaning every second time I try to Uppercut, I have to spend a couple seconds standing around doing nothing waiting for my stamina to refill itself. A couple seconds might not sound like much, but it adds up overtime.Included is a YouTube clip I recorded of this. A note: I was trying to get past this part where you need to jump into an Uppercut into a portal and then walljump a couple more times for almost 15 minutes before I begun recording. And after I ended the recording, I tried for another 45 minutes without ever getting to the other side.Yes. That's an entire hour of me jumping up and down trying to perform a combo move that was as simple as pushing two buttons.And before all the potential angry comments come flooding in, I KNOW ABOUT MICROSOFT GHOSTING. I HAVE DONE THE TEST AND IT SAYS THAT I AM INDEED PRESSING BOTH KEYS. THAT IS NOT THE PROBLEM HERE


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



UPDATE: Yes, I am aware now that you can simply jump into the walljump without Uppercutting, but that still doesn't mean there isn't a frustrating bug that prevents you from using your moves

												+ Charming art style.+ Great soundtrack.+ Good combat...- ...which progressively gets worse.- Frustrating platforming.- Cheap humor which relies on heavy usage of internet memes and references. It wasn't funny. Just stupid.- Plays terribly on a keyboard.I really enjoyed the first two hours of Guacamelee!. But as I continued playing, the flaws started to show. Platforming sequences became rather annoying, the once great combat became a complete mess:As you unlock several abilities, enemies get shields which you can only destroy by using the corresponding ability. Okay, that's not a problem, but when rooms start to get filled with those enemies, all wielding different shields, then it is. Especially when the dimension-switching mechanic is involved. Good luck with that.I can see why people like this game, but the gameplay just feels too clunky and unpolished for me to enjoy. A shame, really.6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												This is the best Metroidvania I've played in a long time. There are parts that mirror the GBA Metroids really well: Flying across multiple screens for secrets, and hidden 'morph ball' tunnels, to name a few. The nostalgia is incredible, but it is very much its own game.The combat system feels pretty decent: It's not anything groundbreaking, but it never gets in the way, and killing crap always feels nice. Throwing enemies was a neat (And fitting) addition, though. With enough enemies on the screen, you can just keep throwing them around, racking up massive combos and killing them without getting touched.The secrets scattered throughout the game (As any Metroidvania should have) are satisfying to find and oh so numerous. What I really enjoyed, though, was rather than having 'energy tanks' that instantly increase your health cap, you have 'heart pieces,' which are instantly reminscent of Zelda. Some areas for secret items get notoriously difficult, and the platforming skills it asks for have been compared to Super Meat Boy (Which, personally, I love a good difficult platformer). The main game, though, is a nice difficulty to get through: It isn't a stroll through the park, but it's not too tricky. And it's still rewarding to finish.The game is also absolutely filled with very-unsubtle references to... Everything. Classic games, internet icons, memes, you name it. The lack of subtlety makes it pretty hilarious. And lastly- This is a game I will never get tired of looking at. It's so gorgeous.Buy this game. Buy it now.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Super fun game. Very colorful, and easy to follow, but there's no voice acting, which isn't a big deal but it would have been nice. Lots of refrences to other games like mario, metroid, and zelda. The platforming is solid, and controls feel pretty good. The combo system seems shallow at first, but as you unlock more moves it becomes very deep and very fun to pull of extremely long combos. Also, the platforming gets hard quick. You need to be good at jumping to complete this game. Luckily checkpoints are pretty close together so you never have to backtrack much and the jumping feels very good and fair. I got it during a humble bundle sale, but it's easily worth 15 or 20 dollars.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												This game has much to offer - quality animation style, bright colours, and a quirky combat system. The game doesn't have much in the way of story, but it doesn't need it. It follows the traditional platformer style - love interest has been captured by some bad guy, good guy pursues bad guy to save love interest - you know how it goes. Anyway, the game starts with baby steps. It can feel slightly frustrating when you first play it, but when you learn all the different "moves/concepts" of the combat system, you appreciate why they started so slowly. This combat system is, quite frankly, fantastic. When the enemies start gaining shields that you have to break, or they go into another dimension that you can't attack, you have to think quickly and act accordingly - button-mashing only gets you so far in this game. The difficulty mark-up is erratic, though. It starts fairly easy, and then the last part of the game is wincingly hard. It almost killed the experience entirely as it was so needlessly hard - I like difficult games, but this game's difficulty can offer you little by way of dodging/returning damage. Sometimes, you just get ♥♥♥♥ed over without doing anything wrong. I eventually triumphed, but only after a fair few tries. I'd recommend this game to anyone. It's fast, colourful, funny and challenging. What more can you ask for?

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Fantastic game! Has a wonderful visual and musical aesthetic, with colorful environments and songs that get stuck in your head for hours afterward (in a good way). It also has a fun sense of humor, with billboards in-game referencing both other games, and memes. There are also a few easter eggs scattered around which i won't spoil. It is definitely a metroidvania style game, with tons of exploration. Controls are tight, and it has a good balance of easy to pick up and play, but challenging. I'd say its about 8 or 9 hours long, but likely has good replayability. Co-op mode also helps with replayability. Glad I bought it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Guacamelee! is a beat'em-up/metroidvania hybrid. Whilst this may sound like a mouthful and a muddled game, what we get is a fun, cool and decently long adventure romp, that is sure to please many people around.Juan is a farmer who, when his love is kidnapped, takes on the mask and becomes a Luchador! Thus he begins his quest to save his love, smash Chozo statues and kick as many skeletons, cacti and bosses to faces Cacala, a mysterious soul who has the form of a skeleton. Along the way Juan unlocks powers from the Chozo statues and some bosses. What is very cool about this game is that many of the powers translate to combat (which, as mentioned, is in a beat'em-up style), such as the [Rooster] Uppercut not only sending the enemies into the air but also giving up a lift mid-jump. Or the Dashing [Derp Derp] helping you kick multiple enemies whilst going a little bit further horizontally.You can also change dimensions to reveal platforms or passages, or turn into a chicken to go into smaller passages. These are used for some challenging, but fun, platforming and puzzle sections.The soundtrack is also great, mixing Latin music with some techno. And almost all songs have alternate versions, for the Light and Dark dimensions. These transition well, and the soundtrack feels relative the the setting and tone of the game, Mexican, Upbeat and overall fun.I finished the game at around 65%-70% completion, so I still had a lot to collect, and I played the game for a good 6 hours (it says 12 as my file deleted... grumble grumble...). This percentage is made up of Health Containers, Stamina Blocks and Orbs (hard-to-find objects for the dedicated). I finished Cacala's final form with difficulty, but not to a extent where it felt cheap or annoying.Guacamelee! is a fun game, with a good soundtrack and an easy 6 hours of gameplay. Looking for a good game to spend some time with over the weekend? Grab Guacamelee! (and the soundtrack) and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Definitely recommend this game for anyone that likes Metroidvania style games. Combat is fluid and fun, and although simple at first, it can be comboed into something intricate. I played on the keyboard, but if you have a controller it will be a more enjoyable experience as the analogue sticks will allow you easier platforming and better angles when performing grappling moves. Probably my favorite part of the game was the art direction and music. The environments and characters are beautiful and just ooze style, and the Spanish theme and music helps really solidify the experience as memorable and unique. The game can be beaten 100% in less than 10 hours, and there isn't much replayability other than hard mode. Still a very solid game though, and one that should be experienced.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												Before starting, I must say that I played with a keyboard, and I don´t know how the game plays with a controller.This game controls are one of the WORST I´ve seen. The developers, (that apparently have♥♥♥♥♥♥for brains) want you to play this game with a contoller. If you play with a keyboard, you´re pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed. The game requires you to do special moves that are a combination of 2 keys, move and special, but here´s how it  works: You first press the move key AND THEN the special. If you press the 2 keys, nothing will happen. You MUST press the movement  key first AND THEN you press the "Special" key to do the Special move. This can get really frustrating in a fight, since you expect your movements to be quick, but performing them is just frustrating and the combat system is extremely flawed.Then you have the platforming. It is TERRIBLE! The game tries too much to be Mega Man, but the difference is that in Megaman, the controls were tight and precise. In Guacamelee, the controls are slidy and most of the times you will fall off the platform.Developers, how about you fix your ♥♥♥♥ing game AND take into consideration the players that DO NOT have a controller0/10Do not buy this

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Absolutely love this game. :-)At its heart, it's a simple metroidvania adventure with melee focus. However, the game shines in everything that it does right. You unlock moves and abilities during the adventure, each neatly fitting in with what you already know. The map makes it clear where you need to go (so it's a bit less exploration), but leaves you enough to encounter. Combat is tight and interesting: you gradually learn how to play without it ever feeling a chore to do.The Mexican theme is nice and (strangely enough) mix well with winks to various games like Zelda (I AM ERROR), Mario (the first boss) and of course metroid (the statues). I probably missed quite some.Also note that like Zelda, there are 2 overlapping worlds (life and death), which add to your arsenal of challenges to overcome.What else is there to say? Bosses are great, the saving and buying is great and there's plenty of chests to explore to upgrade your cash or your life or power-up meter. Enemies can be tough but never frustrating and the design makes use of all the powers you have.Any minusses? Hard to say. I hear keyboard/mice controls aren't that good, but I used a controller, so can't say. And perhaps there was a bit too much storyline at the start, but that's certainly not an issue.All in all: a great recommendation.:-)

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												This is really hard for me.  This game has charm, fun references to famous classics, beautiful art, interesting gameplay ideas and it belongs to one of my favorite genres (Metroidvania).  But for the life of me, I just can't recommend it.  See the gameplay time I have on record?  I can assure you, without any shadow of a doubt, that more than half of it has been spent losing and retrying.  This game starts great, but at some point it becomes brutally difficult.Now, being fair here, the basic portion of the game is easy enough.  The game only becomes harder when you try to find extras and complete challenges.  You might say I shouldn't complain then, but see... this is a Metroidvania.  Its entire premise as a genre is to make exploration fun.  And this game turns exploration into an exercise in maddening frustration.  This should be the best part of the game, and instead it's so bad in comparison to the rest that you'd swear this game started as two different ones that at some point were mashed together for whatever unexplained reason.See, the more you advance the more abilities you unlock.  That's par for the course for the genre, and it's one of the most fun parts of these games.  The problem is that, unlike for all the other games in the genre, all your abilities are available at the same time.  That might seem like a good thing at first, except that now you're forced to remember an alarmingly large amount of special moves, because the game will force you to juggle many abilities at the same time to advance through many areas, which becomes even worse when you have to deal with Super Meat Boy -like scenery.I mean, a game like Super Meat Boy is fun because while it offers a challenge it relies on the simplicity of the controls.  Here you have to deal with the challenge while mastering an increasingly complex set of moves.  This becomes frustrating really fast and it's exacerbated by the fact that the controls are not particularly responsive.  Push Up and the game will do Left instead.  That's not a problem in the middle of walking, but it's definitely a problem when you're trying to do a special move and the game does a different one instead, which will happen half of the time.I can't help but think that most of the positive reviews come from people who don't try to explore in the game, or that never actually bothered to try and finish it.  Or people that have lots of free time so they don't care how much they lose.  Looking at the game's stats, I think it's quite telling that barely over 15% of the people have defeated the last boss.  Clearly most people are giving up way earlier.I have to be as fair as I can here.  Yes, I had a lot of fun with the game, but the frustration has severely trumped it.  That's why I can't recommend it, unless you're either unemployed with lots and lots of time to waste and nothing else to play.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This is one of the best purchases I've made on steam this year.  At its heart, it's a Metroidvania-style game, but the surprisingly good gameplay mechanics, atypical but highly amusing lucha libre setting, endearing art style (nice change from all of the retro/pixel games lately), and witty dialogue make this a clear winner among similar games.  Combos are easy to string together, but still offer a lot of versatility. The platforming aspects, while at times challenging and requiring creativity, are not completely unforgiving and don't require split-second precision (i.e., Super Meatboy).  There are enough side quests to add some flavor, without turning the game into a massive collection of fetch quests.  And there's no need for constant backtracking and revisiting old areas (although you do get skills that unlock certain secret/optional rooms, those entrances are clearly marked on your map so you don't have to waste hours checking every wall in every previous area for a secret).  Bottom line, it's just plain fun.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Fantastic game! Has a wonderful visual and musical aesthetic, with colorful environments and songs that get stuck in your head for hours afterward (in a good way). It also has a fun sense of humor, with billboards in-game referencing both other games, and memes. There are also a few easter eggs scattered around which i won't spoil. It is definitely a metroidvania style game, with tons of exploration. Controls are tight, and it has a good balance of easy to pick up and play, but challenging. I'd say its about 8 or 9 hours long, but likely has good replayability. Co-op mode also helps with replayability. Glad I bought it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Guacamelee! is a beat'em-up/metroidvania hybrid. Whilst this may sound like a mouthful and a muddled game, what we get is a fun, cool and decently long adventure romp, that is sure to please many people around.Juan is a farmer who, when his love is kidnapped, takes on the mask and becomes a Luchador! Thus he begins his quest to save his love, smash Chozo statues and kick as many skeletons, cacti and bosses to faces Cacala, a mysterious soul who has the form of a skeleton. Along the way Juan unlocks powers from the Chozo statues and some bosses. What is very cool about this game is that many of the powers translate to combat (which, as mentioned, is in a beat'em-up style), such as the [Rooster] Uppercut not only sending the enemies into the air but also giving up a lift mid-jump. Or the Dashing [Derp Derp] helping you kick multiple enemies whilst going a little bit further horizontally.You can also change dimensions to reveal platforms or passages, or turn into a chicken to go into smaller passages. These are used for some challenging, but fun, platforming and puzzle sections.The soundtrack is also great, mixing Latin music with some techno. And almost all songs have alternate versions, for the Light and Dark dimensions. These transition well, and the soundtrack feels relative the the setting and tone of the game, Mexican, Upbeat and overall fun.I finished the game at around 65%-70% completion, so I still had a lot to collect, and I played the game for a good 6 hours (it says 12 as my file deleted... grumble grumble...). This percentage is made up of Health Containers, Stamina Blocks and Orbs (hard-to-find objects for the dedicated). I finished Cacala's final form with difficulty, but not to a extent where it felt cheap or annoying.Guacamelee! is a fun game, with a good soundtrack and an easy 6 hours of gameplay. Looking for a good game to spend some time with over the weekend? Grab Guacamelee! (and the soundtrack) and you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 30
												Guacamelee is pure platforming pleasure and perfection. It's fun, stylised and quirky nature shine continuously. It starts off completely accessible and then slowly spirals into higher and higher difficulties by adding new mechanics and scenarios. In the early game you are forgiven for some sloppiness, buy the end game you must be a diety of precision. I really loved this game thoroughly. Highly recommended for people who like old school side scrolling games, an increasing skill curve, ultimately to be challenged, style and charisma in their games, perfect control mechanics, firm but fair solutions based platforming, and occasionally turning into a chicken. Not recommeded for anyone who like hand holding, infinte tutorial prompts, pay to win, one button to win, right click to win, and enjoy endless runners. This is a real bred in the bone platformer.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Mexican Super Metroid.  Pretty good, but definitely needs a controller.  A lot of the jumps to secret areas can be hard, but the game doesn't really punish you at all for missing any jumps (instant respawn, usually on the platform you just jumped from) or dying from enemies.  It maintains a lot of crucial elements (map system, teleport system, unlockable areas early on that you can come back to later) that have been missing from a lot of other indie games that have tried to replicate the genre.  Worth the sale price.

number of helpful: 18 of 38 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This is exactly the sort of game that I usually enjoy, and yet it rubs me the wrong way at every opportunity.The play mechanics are too stiff, so movement and combat just don't feel fun.  When fighting, moves can be utilized in concert to air juggle, to maintain long combos, and to throw enemies at one another, but there really isn't any incentive to use these advanced techniques or even to vary attacks at all.Then there's the Metroid structure, which is too condensed—too simple, too transparent, and too predictable.  You're driven along a very narrow path of progression, and along the way you come across obvious markers for places you'll be able to enter once you receive the proper abilities.  It's just by-the-numbers, and being teased by these blocked-off side paths feels rote when it should feel exciting.  All of the game's puzzle-platforming challenges are characterized by the same workmanlike effort, too.All of this would be disappointing although perhaps not damning, but Guacamelee wears this constant, unfading caca-eating grin that the writing absolutely does not earn.  Many games love to wink at the player, but this one does it while standing over you in an arrogant pose.  The most egregious example I've come across was a hidden QR code.  I posted a screenshot complaining about how presumptuous and frustrating its inclusion is since I don't own any device capable of reading it, and a friend told me that it says "Congratulations! You successfully identified and scanned a QR code! Great job!"  That's it.  That's the kind of reward you can expect for making the effort to discover secret paths.I wish this game was a person so I could punch it in its stupid face.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												I played this version on linux. It seems like an interesting game with an original setting and creative characters. It is a good game unless you play it for a while. The controls are awfull. It also doesn't seem to support a gamepad on linux and I refuse to give my money to microsoft for a x360 gamepad(especially when there are better ones on the market). The keyboard controls are laggy. It is not the problem in the beginning, but later, when the heavy platforming begins, you can't afford to have loose controls. Often there is a pause after you switch dimensions and you are kind of thrown out of action. Sometime you are not sure, if the action was registered already so you press again and the hero does something stupid. Also loading screens in a 2d platformer is an annoyance especially in the modern time where you could load all the asset in ram since they are around ~570 MB.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												It's a unique metroidvania game with art and music that has real soul. When you combine all the abilities and dimensional shifts, some sections present a daunting platforming challenge, but nothing that you can't nail in a handful of attempts. The combat system is deep and satisfying, and while becoming comfortable with combos gives you a satisfying advantage in your DPS, it's never something that's mandatory to fully master. There's plenty of bonus content in the Inferno optional stages that dramatically turn up the heat, with a notable section that really pushes everything you've learned to the limit. The bad guys, with an odd exception, are more interesting than the silent protagonist, but that is fine. Light humor and lots of cultural references.If you have a friend, the drop-in local co-op is a lovely addition.

I'm an adult, I don't have time playing the same thing that I already beaten again and again. I want to TRY the stage 2 as I found it super hard before. You feel "I cannot be bothered with that first stage again, let's just uninstall that sh*t...".Thanks for ruining the game for me, I'm never going to finish it now. I'm going to watch the ending on Youtube and pretend those 16 hours of my life never happened. "Amazing experience - would waste my time again"

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Got this game from the Humble Bundle.The fighting is competently executed for a Metroidvania, and the dodge move is an interesting addition that makes it feel more tactile and stronger.But the game is MAD racist.  Like, everyone's raving about tequila and the Day of the Dead and luchadores in mangled Spanglish and are wearing those Speedy Gonzales ponchos with goofy moustaches.MAD RACIST.  All the characters names are weirdly out-of-place faux-Spanish as well, which is-- again-- appropriative nonsense.Also they use the odious 'Steal the Princess' trope.  The game is just a poorly-written, badly-directed mess that comes across as somebody's high-school Spanish class project on meth: ill thought-out, incompetently executed and racist.  Shame on these developers.I can't play this game anymore.  The soundtrack's alright, though.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Guacamelee is one of the best platforming games i've played the last year.The game is going with a mexican style and everything that relates to it ( Chili peppers, Dias de los Muerto's, Luchador's, Mexican Music, Pinata's) can be found.  Guacamelee is presented in a colourful way and with a very cheery and memorable soundtrack. The fighting system is enjoyable and gets expanded over time with a ton of unlockable moves.  On top of that, it's also possible to earn outfits and upgrades.  To add to the charm, Guacamelee is littered with game referenches to games like Grim Fandango, Super Mario Bros, Castle Crashers and Viva Pinata.Next point of discussion: the puzzles. There are a ton of little side puzzles that are harder than the main-path, but offer small rewards like extra coins for upgrades. These puzzles range from fairly easy to mindbending hard. Sometimes puzzles require you to remember a set of moves to use to get to the end-goal, while other times figuring out which moves you actually need to get the reward is an excersize on itself. To make the puzzles even harder, switching between the living world and the dead world is often necessary to reveal / hide platforms and obstacles. Often you will find yourself thinking about how you will have to tackle a puzzle and learning the muscle memory of the moves before you're actually able to pull it off.The story is fairly straightforward, but because of the small cast of interesting characters and the funny written dialog it feels fun to follow the story. Besides the mainstory, there are always a few little sidemissions to keep things interesting. The aforementioned puzzles are a side-mission on itself.Finally, the bossfights require you to use all the skills you previously learned in the game and are often pretty hard, but you never feel like you will need to google for a solution.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I have enjoyed this game so far. Nice metroidvania with a Luchador twist!The combat is interesting. It has a strong focus on "grappling" with enemies, giving you the ability to throw them around and into other enemies. Combos are a huge part of the game and keeping them going with chaining throws, slams, punches, kicks and headbutts can be very rewarding. The platforming elements are equally rewarding and require you to use an equally large selection of moves to complete some of the puzzles. The game has a nice learning curve. You start off with only a few moves and pick up many more as the the game goes along.  Later on some of the challenges can be a bit frustrating when the controls don't respond as fast as you'd like, but it's nothing that can't be overcome.The map is free roaming, but certain areas are blocked off until you unlock the moves required to access them. In addition going back to areas you've already played through can reveal new secrets to be accessed with your new techniques.The graphics are unique. They look like they could be vector art, the lines are clean and colors sparse but vivid. The many costumes availible keep the variety going. There's also many ireferences to nternet meme and other indie games that are interesting to find.Gameplay: 7.5 Good challenge. Large Variety of moves. Responsiveness can be frustrating durring difficult puzzles.Graphics: 9 Characters with a clean vivid look. Large selection of costumes. Nice backgrounds.  Sound: 7 Nice music and sound effects.Time: 8 You'll get a good chunk of play out of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												More Metroid than 'vania, Guacamelee's greatest strength lies in it's visual style. The lucha-themed world is unique and, with the exception of an unfortunate obsession with memes, is unlike anything I've seen in a game. The fighting is simple, but fun, and the platforming can reach meat-grinder levels of difficulty that will reward sharp reflexes. The only difficulty-related complaint I can think of is that, in order to obtain the best ending, one must complete two platforming segments that are leagues more difficult than anything else in the game. These sections will try your patience, so be prepared!

number of helpful: 11 of 27 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Guacamelee! Gold Edition is a Metroid-vania style action-platformer set in a magical Mexican inspired world. The game draws its inspiration from traditional Mexican culture and folklore, and features many interesting and unique characters. Guacamelee! builds upon the classic open-world Metroid-vania style of games, by adding a strong melee combat component, a new dimension switching mechanic, and cooperative same-screen multiplayer for the entire story. The game also blurs the boundaries between combat and platforming by making many of the moves useful and necessary for both of these. Travel through a mystical and mysterious Mexican world as a Luchador using the power of your two fists to battle evil. Uncover hidden wrestling techniques like the Rooster Uppercut, and Dimension Swap to open new areas and secrets.

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												Not gonna lie, I am not a big fan of the metroidvania genre but this game somehow got me hooked. I think it was mostly because it was a well paced game, it didn't feel either too long or too short, I managed to beat it in about 5 hours but with some extras left that'll probably bump up to about 10 hours. The combat is like marmite, you either love it or hate it. Some find it clunky and others like me find it smooth and fluid. I don't think its the combat itself but rather the animations. Soundtrack is amazing, it really immerses you within the world. I think the best feature of this game is that you can switch between the world of the living and the dead and the style changes dramatically between the two, reminds me a lot of Giana Twisted Dreams, if you enjoy that give this a go and vice versa. Would highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 16 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Do not buy if you dont have lightning fast reflexes.This game is impossible to complete unless you have near-instant reflexes to stuff and can perform multiple complex special moves (with a variety of keys) straight after each other, in sequence. This probably cant be enjoyed by anyone age over 25, as our reflexes start to decline, and the games designers have not accounted for this as there is no skill level setting, you either can do multiple comlpex sequences of keypresses or not.I find this disheartening, as it means I will never complete this game. And it is a fun game, up to a certain point. Then it just asks you to do things which are basically impossible unless you want to sit on one screen for three hours, trying over and over again to master a set of keypresses (and how has anyone even got that much patience?).Up until "the" point, where I threw in the towel, I was having a good time, the game is funny, has a good artstyle and besides the hyper-reflex requirement, the gameplay was really nice. Its a shame that it cant be finished due to a lack of difficulty setting.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												There aren't too many fighting games on Linux, so this game has little competition right now. It's a solid beat-em up featuring lots of chain moves, an emphasis on out-thinking your opponents and strategies rather than just button mashing and even something approaching a PLOT. As a Luchador brought back from the dead, you must save El Presidente's daughter and defeat Calacas before his plans to rule both the living and the dead can be completed.I will point out that you should pad the walls of the room where you play this because it will, sooner or later, engage your gamepad in high velocity transit from your hands towards some solid object. The platforming in this game requires thought, timing and accurate button presses, and there are times ....Even so, it is doable. You just have to perservere, although it will be a while before I attempt to get the Tule Tree orb again...

Posted: April 18, 2014
												SalsaSuckerPunch 2: Electric Boogaloo is a testament to multi-genre gaming. Produced by extremely independent and extremely racist game developer Juicestraw Studios, SalsaSuckerPunch 2 comes at you from all directions with pulse-pounding action. With its inuitive design, SalsaSuckerPunch 2 is not only a cooking game; it's a MMORPG; it's a puzzle game; it's a racing game; it's a minigame collection; it's a buttonmasher; it's a second-person shooter; it's a crafting game; it's a Japanese produced rhythm game; it's a flying simulator; it's a football game like Madden; it's a board game. Players will enter the life of protagonist Tony Tortilla, a Mexican stereotyped chef, whose quest for magical Mexican jumping beans will leave the player in gut busting guffaws and heart-wrenching sadness. SalsaSuckerPunch 2: Cindy-Loo-Who is a spicy kick to the mouth; it will change your perspective on gaming in general.In summary,8/10Needs more subtle racism.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												Despite the name and how the theme may seem a bit... corny and stereotypical? This game is fantastic. The Day of the Dead and the imagery associated with it has been a popular fashion/photography/art trend for while and it grows stronger with each passing year. This game captures that theme perfectly, but presents it in a fresh and funky way. The visuals are spectacular, the music is fitting, and the mechanics are ridiculously fun while being extremely easy to learn. (This game handles tutorials so well. It's almost a thing of art.) There are also plenty of optional side things for you to do in the game if you want to increase the challenge. If you love action platformers, pick this up ASAP.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												When Monaco and The Swapper were part of the same Humble Bundle, I picked it up without hesitation.  Guacamelee! was part of the same bundle.I never would have bought it on it's own, but I had it, and it seemed like a low-commitment game, so I gave it a shot.  As it turns out, it's a really, really solid platformer!  Yes, my expectations were low, but it didn't just exceed them... this game is genuinely fun, and I'm making time in my day to come back to it.It's more about pulling off well-timed button combos than it is solving puzzles, but there's a good mixture of both -- especially if you're looking for Easter Eggs.  If you enjoyed classic console platformers, you're really going to enjoy the elements of this game that pay hommage to those.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												It's like I'm playing Super Metroid as a luchadore!  Definitely scratches that metroidvania itch if you like the genre.  Has a very catchy soundtrack, good combat once you wrap your head around it (tip: dodge dodge doge, protip: get the skeleton costume that let's you have infinite stamina, it's like cheating), and is just difficult enough not to drive you nuts like Dark Souls or the like but still provide challenge, and is just plain fun.  One of those games you can go back to 10 years from now and still have a good time.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Think metroidvania in 1080p, a flat, colorful, and borderless art style, tighter controls, and a contageous sense of humor. This game really shines in its gameplay. The game is a brawler at heart, and its tight controls lend itself to a easy-to-learn, hard-to-master combo system that is satisfying to traverse through as you purchase more moves. The story is not novel-worthy; it involves a few unconnected subplots that eventually lead up to facing the grand boss. The characters, however, are memorable and all have their own unique, though twisted and somewhat ADD, quirks.The bosses are challenging and satisfying. There are moments when the game locks you in an enclosed space and force a battle between you and waves of enemies. Not only do these battles reward you with a pinata and a sense of satisfaction after, they also force you to learn the combos before you proceed (some enemies can only be broken with a certain type of move). There are rooms that are dedicated to puzzle-platform rewards. They're almost always completely optional but yield a nice reward (like a heart piece) and a sense of achievement after.I loved this game to the core.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Guacamelee first appealed to me because of the art and humor. Since I haven't played platformers in a long time it took quite a lot of practise to progress once you get halfway through the game. Not that the game is too unforgiving, the progression of difficulty is very well done. The combo system works very smoothly and you need to adjust your tactics according to the arenas ,especially in hard mode; it is very satisfying to chain many attacks into one giant combo. A lot of extra stuff is present in the game like hidden treasures and the challenges, which are very diverse and take persistence and concentration to complete. Some parts were borderline frustrating for me to complete with my skill, a top 5:1. Javier hard mode (skill cancel and quick second strikes, don't try for 3h continuously like me, take some breaks)2. Flame face hard mode (his skills + dealing with yellow skeletons)3. Secret jumping puzzle in Sierra Morena (vanishing platforms of doom)4. Bone on Bone achievement (flying bones and lightning is a deadly combo)5. The 4 lightning shooting skeleton arena in the Great Temple on hard mode (4 x lightning = 256 x the trouble)I really brushed up my platform & beat'em up skills after they gathered dust for some years!TLDR: An awesome and hilarious platformer with a large variety of puzzles, arenas, and tough boss fights, beautiful artwork, and brutal challenges and achievements.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Just finished defeating the last boss and the game has been amazing. Not only is it a good Metroidvania game, you can't button mash to win, making you think of what to do and discover how to do certain parts through trial and error. The artstyle is also amazing and original, a Day of the Dead metroidvania? Whoever thought of that was a genius. And it also provides quite a challenge. Kinda on the short side, but the pacing was good so I don't really mind.Although there are some flaws, like the fact that they'll gladly throw a room of enemies at you where you get overwhelmed too much if you're not good with the combat, which seems a bit cheap when they do it rather early.Also, with steam workshop, you can play as Johnny Bravo or Bayonetta beating the crap out of dead people. Need I say more? A definite recommendation.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Back in the day I played lots of platformers, and it seems like Guacamelee has taken all the best features from those games, and thrown in some fun new stuff. The platforming and melee fighting seem a bit simple and even quite easy at first, but once you learn all the special moves and attacks, things suddenly get a whole lot more complicated. I suspect that the game might be a little bit on the easy side for some hardcore gamer, but for me the difficulty was just perfect - some of the areas were very tricky and frustrating, but never too frustrating, and while most areas won't cause anyone too much trouble, the game never gets too easy either. The combat system feels really good once you get used to it and the melee fights are fun, especially the boss fights.What I love just as much as the actual gameplay though, is the art design and music of Guacamelee. The whole Mexican theme with some totally ridiculous stuff (crazy special moves such as Rooster Uppercut or Goat Fly, a special ability called Pollo Power that turns you into a chicken, etc...), thrown in is simply awesome. The funny little details and some of the silly dialogue actually made me laugh, I love the humour in Guacamelee. It's not a very long game, even with the DLC and the Hard Mode. According to Steam it took me 30 hours to find all the treasures and secrets and to finish the game in normal difficulty, and then another time in Hard Mode. And thus Guacamelee became the first and only (and probably the last) game ever where I've unlocked all the achievements!Guacamelee! is also the winner of the prestigious Tomiboo's GOTY 2013 award!tldr; Great game, buy it NOW.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												FANTASTIC. Guacamelee = A metroidvania with a mexican luchdor and a pretty damn good melee combat system. Guacamelee is what's called a "metroidvania". An open world 2D platformer with certain paths restricted until you obtain new traversal abilities. You can also backtrack to previous areas with your newly aquired abilities and find power ups and other secrets. As far as this genre goes, Guacamelee is one of the best.Graphics  - It's a great looking game. The art is colorful and fits the game perfectly. Whatever outfit your character is wearing, the animation is smooth and fluid. In addition, there are a lot of little nods and easter eggs to pop culture and gaming sprinkled in and it really helps to give the world character. Story - No surprises here. Typical "rescue the princess" story we've had since the dawn of time. It serves the game well enough, but don't expect any curveballs. Gameplay - Control is tight and spot on. Moving around the levels feels great and you're consistenly given new abilities so it never feels boring. There's also a healthy dose of combat that has enough depth to keep you interested. Those moves you use to open up new areas? They also function as attacks. By the end of the game, you have a great set of skill at your disposal to take out the bad guys. This bring me to one of my few complaints about this Guacamelee. Enemies will gain one to 5 different types of shields in addition to being in one of two worlds you can switch between, the enemy only being attackable in one world. It can be a bit much to deal with later in the game when there is so much going on, especially when the enemies seem to get their shield back almost instantly. Small gripe, but not enough to ruin the game. One more thing. There are some downright devious platforming sections. Nothing as bad as Super Meat Boy or IWBTG, but they can get a bit hairy. Especially when you have to double jump, wall bounce, uppercut, wall bounce, etc... all in one combination. If you're into that, you'll love this game and you do feel great when you finally nail it. Replay Value - There is a "good" ending if you find all the hidden pieces of a certain item, secrets to find and areas to go back and get to 100%. There are also a few sidequests, and a "hard" mode. Once you've beaten the game and gotten the good ending though, you've seen just about everything. If you're even remotely a fan of metroidvanias, or platformers in general. Pick up Guacamelee. It's one of the best in the genre and more than that, it's a simply a great game.

It is a beautiful, well designed Metroidvania full of style, humor, and imagination.
