Posted: January 4, 2014
												Overall, this is one of my favorite games of the year (and I probably would never have bought it except that I saw it on sale during the Steam sale).  The combat is surprisingly fun given that there really are only a handful of moves, and the pace at which you receive new powers throughout the game keeps things fresh.One issue, though not affecting my overall feeling about the game, is the occassionally frustrating platforming sections (especially some of the Tula Tree sections that are necessary to progress in the game).  As some other reviewers have mentioned, the control scheme can be awkward during these platforming sections.  In particular, the assignment of the light/dark world changes to the right trigger can make it difficult when needing to switch worlds while jumping.  I think it would have been better if there had at least been an option to remap the controls to be able to map the world switch to a face button.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Guacamelee is like a challenging cross between Mario and Super Meat Boy.  It is equal parts fighting enemies and solving difficult puzzles to progress to new areas.  A controller is definately recommended for this game.  There are many fighting and jumping moves that require quick and timely button presses to succeed.  Two player co-op is fun but you'll want to work out an agreement with your partner as to who controls the switching back and forth from living to dead world.  The art and styling of the game is a great bonus.  As you struggle on the next puzzle you can spend a few resting seconds to admire the colorful environments.  Many subtle placed references to internet or gaming icons.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												

Posted: April 14, 2014
												A wonderful Metroidvania platformer brawling game, with vivid and fun graphical styling, a decent sense of humor and a huge amount of references to other indie games and internet memes. Platforming in this open world relies on the use of an ever expanding list of new methods to get a little bit more movement from special attacks, thus allowing further progress into new zones or back into secret treasures hidden in hard to get too places. Failure rarely ever sets you back very far, usually one or two jumps back in most places, but in some more rare and almost always optional content places a mistimed jump or incorrect sequence of joystick motions and button presses can net a frustrating loss of work. A gamepad is really suggested. The brawling elements are pretty fun, combos and special powers are nice and fun to use, but attack button mashing plus the use of throws is all that is needed for most fights early in the game. Overall difficulty is pretty good, and not too hard for all the necessary plot content, with the most difficult jumping puzzles and fights (other than boss battles) being left purely for the got a have it all collectable and achievement hunters.

Posted: April 15, 2014
												Great game!I got it with the humble bundle pack, but if I knew about it beforehand, I would have paid full price. It's challenging, fun, and diverse. I'll admit that after the second playthrough, combat got annoying, but not enough to stop playing. There are references in about every space you travel through. I couldn't help but stop and admire all the thought that went into putting these refernces in. The controls are a bit challenging to get a hang of, but the game does this on purpose. Getting a hang of the controls is usually half the puzzle. And hard mode was was exactly that, hard. Some games will give you lower health and slap on a "hard" in there. Guacamelee accually tries to give you a challenge the second time around. The only huge let-downer to the game is there's no reason to go back after you've 100%'d hard mode. That being said, I was pleased with the amount of content. Buy the game, you won't regret it.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												This is a style of game like Super Metroid, wherein new abilities acquired steadily throughout allow the player to access paths that are initially blocked. Said abilities are useful in both movement and combat. Like a punch that propels the player quickly forward, used to thump butts OR reach difficult areas.Many a pop culture reference can be found, along with chuckle-worthy dialog throughout the three to five-hour campaign. Hidden or optional areas not necessary to "beat" the game provide the greatest challenge in terms of combat and/or platforming.All in all a good time. Five stars, relative to it being an indie download type of game. Olé!

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Metroidvania, Luchadores, and a Samurai-Jack-esque art style. Yeah, I can get on board with this. And co-op, although local only, which on the PC is a crying shame. I'd love a co-op metroidvania experience. The gameplay is solid, the art style is charming. My only other quibble is the somewhat shoddy handling of character selection. In a single-player game (which let's face it, you're almost certainly playing on PC since again, no online co-op), you start the story as Juan and can only switch to the second main character, Tostada, after the introductory area. Even if you do, the game seems to not acknowledge Tostada's presence at all during the story, with NPCs still talking as though they were dealing with Juan. It's not a huge thing, but it's just sort of a missing feature that really would have knocked this out of the park on an already impressive game. It's a 4/5 for me that easily could have been a 5/5 if they'd clean up how the game handles it if you want to play Tostada and involve her more in the story. An alternate opening along with some minor edits to dialogue would do the trick nicely.

												HOLY CRAP GUYS. GUYS.This is a metroidvania-style game. Posted: December 28, 2013
												Wonderful Mexican-themed Metroidvania game with great hand-to-hand combat and occasionally diabolical platforming (generally easy other than the secret levels required to unlock the orbs). The comparison to Metroid is not a token one -- the Metroid references are so explicit as to leave no doubt that it is a deliberate homage. It's packed with other easter eggs, too, including references to Zelda, Megaman, and a hidden message in the language of Fez.It's gorgeous (both audio and video) and perfectly polished. There are so many little touches that it's clear the game was a labour of love; my favourite part is probably the appropriate chicken-form for each costume.Easily one of the best platformers ever made.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Well I have had a cracking time playing through this game. It uses the common platform mechanic of getting new special moves as you progress through the game, allowing you to access areas that were inaccessible before. The combat is satisfying and allows you to string some fairly meaty combos together as well as using the main power moves. There are some pretty challenging platform sections that had me pulling my hair out for a bit, but not so hard that it makes you lose interest & give up the challenge.I have never played a game with this kind of art style and atmosphere before. The graphics and the music really draw you in; the whole Mexican Luchador vibe is pulled off perfectly, and has a nice story with some funny touches. I have completed the game, but will go back to it to get those last few secret sections/chests etc. And I think the challenge arenas down in hell will keep me occupied for a while!Would thoroughly recommend this to any one who likes platforming games, with a good bit of combat as well. Brilliant fun.

Posted: April 15, 2014
												This game delivers so much more than expected!  It looks like an easy mario/metroid-type game and the first few minutes into the game make you think this even more.  However, each stage introduces new mechanics to both the fighting and the dungeon puzzles which make this game a real winner.  By the end, there's so much you have to think about just to win battles against basic enemies, let alone the exciting final boss fights.I would highly recommend this game and make sure you give it at least an hour or two in before you really judge the game!

Posted: November 14, 2013
												What a fantastic metroidvania! I cannot overstate just how well done Guacamelee is all together. The game  has an original feel largely thanks to to its animation influenced art style. The game has loads of humor to boot and it is just darn fun. While combat is a staple of metroidvanias, Guacamelee has a beat  'em up feel to its system. Combat is done by chaining punches together with the main attack button. As you progress you will learn four combat special moves executed with another button or key and a direction. These can be chained together for long combos. Also there is a grab move that can be executed on enemies have taken enough damage. The basic system is simple and common to many fighting games and brawlers, but I have not encountered it in a 2D metroidvania before. Guacamelee also has a heavy focus on precise platforming sections. These sections can range in difficulty, from simple to hand-cramping tough.The aerial acrobatics that your character is put through defy easy description, or even recallable button input. But after that last time he had to do a wall run, air dash, dimensional phase, double jump, flaming uppercut, and punch for that little extra distance.... I really wished I could have just reach in and given him a good length of rope.Overall a really great game though.

Posted: April 4, 2014
												ULTRA FUN side-scrolling lucha action game. Very easy to get into, but over time the Luchador's abilities pile up, making for some interesting combos (an NPC will "train" you with some of the mashups that you can do with the abilities). Some fights are very tough, I relied on my buddy to finish some of the bosses (taking turns resurrecting during a battle). Highly recommended for any kind of gamer - this is the type of game that you can just pick up and go anytime. Perfect for plays in between your more serious games.

												This game delivers so much more than expected!  It looks like an easy mario/metroid-type game and the first few minutes into the game make you think this even more. Posted: April 5, 2014
												The early part of this game is colorful, charming, and highly enjoyable.  The music is great, the references are quirky and it briskly evolves into a fun and comedic metroid/castlevania with a intricate combat system and satisfying level design with purposeful rooms that teach you more about your repitoire of available actions.  Then just before the final world, it becomes a convuluted version of Super Meat Boy, with an sudden and jarring spike in difficulty, twitch reaction based trial and error sequences, and unforgiving checkpoints.  You know, to put it simply, the reason why Super Meat Boy works and this game does not is that SMB's controls only require that you jump at the right place and at the right time.  In Guacamelee, you not only need to jump at the right place and at the right time, but also in the right dimension while dashing, power punching, double jumping, wall running, and goat flying. Logicstically, the puzzles aren't even hard to solve, they're just borderline impossible to execute on the first 20 tries.   As a result, a game that started with the promise of having fun in a colorful world of Mexican towns and countrysides becomes a frustrating excercise of piloting my awkwardly moving avatar from one abstract platform surrounded by sawblades to another abstract platform surrounded by spikes... the sudden twist is alarming and if it's something this studio doesn't realize, or are unwilling to admit, they're next title will be a scary proposition. It's a unnerving choice in game design to lock away the "best ending" behind the hardest machinations of the game, and provide a "regular ending' that so morose and completely unexpected that it clashes with the light-hearted tone established in the other 99% of the the game prior.  When a player doesn't even know that he or she has to collect secret orbs that are well hidden in the game it makes the default ending provide absolutely no pay off for the player's actions up to that point.  "I know we promised you cake, but here's a dirty boot instead!"  The default ending really destroyed my morale to continue further in the game.  And the "true" ending serves as no substantial improvement in resolving the remaining storylines presented in the game.  I mean, who was the Guardian of the mask?  Why did the villians have more personality and background than any of the good main characters?  What happened to all of the unresolved story lines: did the devil stay as a chicken?  What happened to the Jaguar Man? Even if we saved the girlfriend in distress is the world of the living/dead still threatened with evil spirits and skeletons? At best we only see a kiss and then the credits roll at the end, as if that solved all of the major world issues.  For the amazing writing and world up to that point, I expected better. What's even worse is that the either ending of the game is wholly irrelevant when considering that the main character can freely travel between the world of the living and the dead.  The sullen ending provided by the default ending is absolutely ludicrous given that if the hero just pressed LB, he'd immediately be in the world of the dead and be reunited with his childhood love interest.  No wait, LB makes you dodge, I meant RB.  Wait, what was RB for again... goat run?  Belly flop?  Turn into a chicken?  Great music, colorful world, charming casts of antagonists, but ultimately a large mistep in game design puts pressure on the mechanics of Guacamelee turning it from a silly and inspired romp into a frustrating tedious platformer.

												Great game!I got it with the humble bundle pack, but if I knew about it beforehand, I would have paid full price. It's challenging, fun, and diverse. I'll admit that after the second playthrough, combat got annoying, but not enough to stop playing. There are references in about every space you travel through. I couldn't help but stop and admire all the thought that went into putting these refernces in. The controls are a bit challenging to get a hang of, but the game does this on purpose. Getting a hang of the controls is usually half the puzzle. And hard mode was was exactly that, hard. Some games will give you lower health and slap on a "hard" in there. Guacamelee accually tries to give you a challenge the second time around. The only huge let-downer to the game is there's no reason to go back after you've 100%'d hard mode. That being said, I was pleased with the amount of content. Buy the game, you won't regret it.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												This game is an homage to the games from my childhood. The whole early 1990's gameplay; look and feel seems to be a fad these days with this whole indie/pixel-art  "sub-culture." While I usually tend to skip these games, Gucameelee!'s charm reeled me in and the whole experience simply nails it in my book. The presentation, story, combat, and soundtrack are beyond top notch (especially when you consider it was developed by a team of 10!) However, this whole torturous love/hate relationship that exists in some of the later platforming levels (perhaps a cheap Logitech controller is partly to blame) might turn some people off. Having said that, at $15 full price (and as cheap as $3 on a Steam Sale) it is virtually a no-brainer purchase if you yearn for a good platformer set within a quirky and memorable world as a break from an ocean of modern day Triple A games.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												In Guacamelee! you play as the underdog luchador hero Juan, fighting to save the doncella hermosa, El Presidente's daughter from the clasps of Calaca, the king of the dead. You play in a beautiful landscape, with a vibrant, blocky texture to it, and the music combines traditional, mexican mariachi with electro pop, resulting in a really awesome soundtrack.I can easily say that this game gave me the most enjoyment a 2d platformer ever has in the past. With many hours of content, including some really fun and fluid combat which doesn't get old quickly, as well as some very well done megaman-style platforming challenges, this game is definitely worth the money. 10 out of 10.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Guacamelee oozes style and polish from every frame. It's a pitch-perfect Metroidvania (explorable map, powerups to open new paths, etc) with satisfying combo-driven brawler combat that stays both entertaining and challenging from start to finish. The game is also loaded with secrets that provide extra challenge for the truly hardcore, including a gauntlet-style challenge and (in the Infierno bonus content) a series of challenge rooms that test your timing, speed, and combat savvy.The game also supports two-player (local only, I believe) coop, with the second player as the luchadora Tostada. A solo player can also swap to Tostada if they choose, though the game's script will still refer to the player as "Juan."Playing with a controller is strongly recommended.

												This game is spectacularly fun, humorous, colorful, musical, etc. etc. I honestly really like it. The art and plot are really great. That being said, this is one of the trickiest platformers I've played. If I didn't have a stubborn perseverence, I would've ragequit a while ago. As it is, I do have to take breaks and remind myself that, despite its difficult keyboard commands, this game isn't impossible. I recommend it. If you're patient. And if you're not...you should probably take it slowly. xD

Posted: January 8, 2014
												A welcomed change to all the other Metroivania wannabes. Guacamelee offers a fresh mix of style and gameplay one would expect from this sub-genre of 2D games. It avoids the weapon based shooting combat of other games by employing a hand-to-hand combo system that is quite fun to play with and can be pretty rewarding on harder difficulty because it requires the player to use a variety of moves to be successful. You'll find yourself excited to come across enemies just so you can pull off huge combos with wrestling moves in the style of Lucha libre. Defeating enemies will reward you with money that can be used to purchase more combat moves, outfits that offer stat boosts, or upgrading the health and stamina bar. While not fighting a somewhat limited set of enemies, Guacamelee's main gamepaly is actually the level traversing and its focus on platforming. At its best, the game requires the player to use Juan's, our protagonist, short list of power-ups such as the standard double jump to the wall running ability in order to manuever through the environment.  Another power-up that allows Juan to switch between two worlds on the fly adds to the clever level design. At its worse, it is basic jumping from one platform to another, but that doesn't detract from gameplay at all. Players will be searching hidden areas to find chests and more powerups. If you want to know what they are, you'll have to play the game yourself.Guacamelee is not only fun to play, but visually and aurally, it's a treat. The art is cartoony with a Mexican theme and littered around the environment are some nods to videogames such as Super Mario, Zelda, and of course Metroid. There are geeky internet memes injected into the settings as well. The music is played in mariachi style that incorporates sythn sounds and beats with the traditional classical guitar and horns that's usually upbeat and fast pased. Some of soundtrack has two versions, which you can listen to by switching between the two worlds. They're all very enjoyable to listen to and nicely accompany each setting of the game.Guacamelee is a somewhat short but ultimately satisfying game to play. Experienced players will finish it in around five hours while skipping certain hidden items. Doing everything and getting 100% will extend the game to an extra hour or two. Doing so will offer an extra ending. For everyone else, you'll be enjoying a good 8-10 hours of gamplay so do yourself a favor and pick up Guacamelee!

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Guacamelee! is a very fun action platformer, with some very innovative puzzling. It has some open world elements, somewhat of a level up system, and some costumes you can acquire. The action doesn't feel too repetitive, and the boss battles are fun.  Get Guacamelee! if you think you have the reflexes, or would like to find out if you are epileptic.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												The best Luchador/Day of the Dead Metroid-Vania game this year!

Posted: January 8, 2014
												I never expected to feel as compelled and excited by playing a 2D platformer as I did with Guacamelee. Its hook is a perfectly crafted gameplay, a brilliant level design, and a unique humorous tone.Everything is built around the abilities of Juan, the main character, and this seems to be the key of its success in all its fronts.The game world is progressively unlocked as you acquire new powers, which allow you to access those small spots you saw at the beginning, that you were not able to access, but you knew you'll be able to reach at some point. It reminds me of those magic moments I had while playing "Metroid" (SNES), or the awesome dungeons of any old-Zelda game.The combat system is brilliant, and this is thanks to the design of the foes inhabitating this crazy Mexican-fantasy-world. Each enemy type is built around one of your combat abilities, so as you progress in the game, and you get new skills, a new enemy enters the scene, asking you to masterize that new ability you just acquired. Without noticing, you end up fighting big groups of creatures, each one of a different type, asking you to combine ALL of your abilities in some sort of coordinated choreography. The best part is that you do not even notice of how you end up "playing piano" with your gamepad. And this feels really good. Everyone would like to learn to play a piano, right?Totally recommended.

Posted: August 13, 2013
												The very definition of "short but sweet". This game is a mix of Metroidvania-style progression, beat 'em up combat (with a pretty deep combo system), and some pretty challenging puzzle-platforming. As far as Metroidvania games go, this has to be one of my favourites; the pacing is excellent, combat is very fun, and the platforming is challenging without becoming excessively frustrating. Also, the game has a unique and striking art style, some great humor, and plenty of in-jokes and references to other games.The game only took me around 5 hours to complete (without finding all the secrets), but I loved every minute. Highly recommended.

												To start off, I love the cartoony animation style of this game; it's so bright and colourful. But this game offers much more than beautiful visuals, fight mechanics which are simple to start with but can be chained together to create interesting combos, complex and fun level designs, a great soundtrack filled withupbeat and racy Mexican music with an electronic tone, a sense of humour which is self-referential to its platformer genre and pop-culture, genuinely tough special enemies and boss fights which for me, were some of the hardest I've played in a long time. 												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, but it's less of a Metroid-vania and more of just a linear platforming beat-em-up adventure. Usually in a Metroid-vania type of game you're supposed to come back to areas that require a certain mobility powerup or equivalent to proceed to the next area, but this game was pretty straightforward. Posted: December 24, 2013
												Absoutely amazing game.  The story is comical but also not just a joke.  The music and art are phenomenal.  If I had to describe it using other games as a basis of comparisson, the map and sidescrolling non-linear gameplay reminds me a LOT of castlevania symphony of the night and the metroid franchise which is a GREAT thing.  The combat itself has a simple combo, grapple, and special attack system that works very well and is highly responsive.I have seen the negative reviews complain about difficulty, but an important thing to remember is the games of the era this game is created in the essence of were all very difficult and chalenging.  This game is very non-punitive though.  For example, when you die from a platforming section, you simply spawn back to the start of the room.  Yes, you must complete whatever series of jumps or wall flips it has for you, but it doesn't rewind you to your last save point to do so.  In short, it has the skill elements from games of the past, without the frustration that can go along with it.

Also, the in-game jokes, references and tidbits are priceless, alongside many other things such as deeply-seeded Mexican culture featurettes (or "culturettes) of which the game is not lacking. A challenging, fun, nostalgic and hilarious game with everything we love of pop culture, Mexican culture and videogame culture. On top of it all, the localization (if you can speak Spanish and recognize Mexican slang) is beyond priceless. Give it a go, for you will not regret it!

												this game incites a yearning to be able to call meheeco your home, to wear a sombrero, to be able to speak spanish, to be able to become a luchador, eat guacamole and salsa and tortilla chips everyday, and possibly settle down with a beautiful native woman in the middle of the desert after you kill an evil mexican skeleton dressed as a charro and be happy making tequila for the rest of your days.  but then you remember that this is all just a game and that mexico is actually a place that thousands of people are trying to get away from every day by risking their lives to possibly clear a border and make it into a country that doesn't want them there and that has a multitude of issues of its own, possibly find a job that more than likely pays them next to nothing, and constantly fret about having to take care of themselves and their families, all the while desperately evading detection of their status as an illegal immigrant.  but hey, this game is pretty cool.  you can headbutt stuff, the combat overall is very satisfying, it's paced well, you can do wrestling moves, and the music is dope.  however, the seemingly never-ending "shoutouts" to memes and other video games is a bit overbearing, the side missions are kind of dumb, and the constant switching between dimensions later in the game can get a little annoying, especially in platforming segments.  the game as a whole is really fun though, and gets surprisingly challenging in the last few hours.  it makes you really want some mexican food too.

												The story was a bit lackluster, but the dialogue and the situations were hilarious. Combat is unique with endless possibilities for approaching a fight. Posted: February 19, 2014
												I'd highly recommend this game to any metroid (or metroidvania) fan looking for another game to play. I thought Guacamelee was well-presented in both its music and art-style. The controls are responsive, the game mechanics make the gameplay decently challenging, and I had a very fun 5 1/2 hour experience with no dull moment throughout the game. There are lots of secrets hidden throughout the map and the level design is so well done that you can find the majority of these secrets as you progress through the story with little-to-no additional backtracking. The melee combat is very rewarding to players who actually take the time to learn the mechanics rather than relying on button-smashing and, in general, dying is pretty forgiving - leaving you a "screen" or two away from where you last died. I guess this respawn system can help keep you from getting frustrated in certain hidden areas of the game though... Anyway, if you like Metroidvania-style games, pick this up. Even if you don't enjoy them, but like beat-em-ups or any other kind of action game, give this game a chance. I guarantee you'll at least get a few laughs out of it.

Posted: March 14, 2014
												Simply superb "metroidvania" platformer. The game oozes character and style. The platforming is tight and intuitive (a controller is seriously recommended), the art style is fantastic as well as the world it immerses you in. Once again, this is a game that knows how to use humour to make things even more enjoyable.The difficulty balance is perfect, as you progress in the game, not only do you gain new abilities and skills but you really learn how to use them to maximum effect. My favourite aspect of the gameplay would have to be the puzzle-like platform sequences to reach hard to find chests. You'll find this game is both a test of problem solving and dexterous skill.Verdict: A must-play! No one should miss out on this superb game (unless of course you are irrationally prejudiced against platformers.)

Posted: February 5, 2014
												The MarsupialPugilist grants Guacamelee! the title of Steam's premier metroidvania luchador game. Almost everyone else has expressed the same sentiment, but coming from The MarsupialPugilist, cousin to the luchador, this is a ringing endoresement.Guacamelee's combat is simple, but it oozes polish, power, and considerable depth. Characters themselves have little depth, but that is negligible given the fact that they all manage to have purpose, and more personality than most games can hope to achieve.Guacamelee! is worth $15, but it wouldn't hurt to wait on it, given the fact that the game has gone on sale a few times on Steam already. The MarsupialPugilist doesn't care, as long as you buy the game.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												First review! (was gonna do Deus Ex but they took it off)Recently finished, not 100%Story, boy saves girl, doesnt really matter in this type of gameArt style, like it or you don't, there are screen shots available. I like it personally, works with the whole (Mexican/mariachi/wrestler) theme which we don't see alot of. Easter eggs and other game references through out the some of the levels. Music, terrific again works with the theme Gameplay, 2D platformer/beat'em upPlatforming is hard, for me, becuase I suck, not the game's fault, the controls are fine (I used a xbox controller), timing is the key here, sometimes it's frustrating but there are plenty of checkpoints and if you die falling off a platform you'll just respawn at the previous platform you were standing on before you jumped off; unless you fell on another platform that is way down at the bottom of the level, and because there is no fall damage, you won't die and just gonna have to make your way back up. Fighting mechanic, basic puches and 4 special moves combined together along with jumps and rolls/dodges to create about 20 or so combos; there's fun side quest that serves as a tutorial for you to try out these combos, but other than that, it's not really necessary to memorize them since after the damage upgrades, which can be acquired pretty early in the game by spending orbs that you get from killing enemies (the higher the combo the more orb you get after the battle) and the abusing of the throw mechanic (which knocks down/back other enemies but does stop the combo), most enemies will be dead way before you finish the combo. Boss fights are not that hard either, learn their attack pattern dodge, lay down a combo, repeat. Finding and getting to the treasure is the best part of the game for me, even though at that point of the game you don't really need the orbs/health/stamina upgrades that the treasure chests contain; but it's alot of fun because they requires you to use a combination of moves you've learned through out the game to pull it off. Which brings me to a problem I have with the game - the map. One way to find the hidden paths is by indentifying the blurred-pixelated spots on the map that aren't explored , but some of the areas on the map are also blurred-and pixelated looking, places like the edge of cliff, both ends of a stage, down at a bottomless pit, in the middle of the sky... So alot of time are spent on jumping off cliffs or the edges and looking for walls to grab onto just to use one of the game mechanics (SPOILER) to ___ across the stage just to clear up the map to make sure you didn't miss anything. And that still won't clear up the whole map!Replayability, low, unless you want to try out a harder difficulty, since the game doesn't allow you to go back to collect all the treasues you missed or finish the challenges after entering the final stageFinal score 9/10 half a poitn for map; half a point for challenge room difficulty (yeah there's a challenge room) and replayability

Posted: July 15, 2014
												Guacamelee is crazy fun. One of the tags on Steam is "MetroidVania" which is absolutely accurate. And I f*cking LOVED both of those games which is probably why I'm digging this so hard.Super Metroid is one of the highlights of my gaming time on SNES. That game was "open world" before "open world" was "open world". I would spend so much time traveling back and forth being frustrated until that oh-so satisfying "EUREKA!!!!" moment. And Castlevania, while being a lot more linear in the early games, was a game that was VERY demanding about timing and learning enemy movements. I always hated it at first (like those god damn floating Medusa heads) but once you start to get it, it becomes rhythmic.And then I saw the Mario reference and I was completely sold. It took me a little over an hour of play to really feel this way but... yeah. 10/10 will continue playing and be frustrated and then conquering those frustrations and feeling like a god (or at least feeling like whatever lowly god is really good at wall jumping and then headbutting things).

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Soul Reaver + Castle Crashers + Castlevania: SOTN = Guacamelee!Did I mention this game is amazing?  Well it is.  It's vibrant, detailed, fluid, challenging, everything desireable in a platformer or a brawler.  The thing that really amazed me the most, was that every time I thought, "ok.  Neat trick.  I guess I'll spend the rest of the game doing this.  I can dig that," it turned out there was an even cooler set of moves, and puzzles that required them, right around the corner.  I thought I had seen it all from these kind of games, and boy was I wrong.  Specials affect combat and exploration at the same time in a way that ought to make most competitors jealous, and it keeps throwing them in at a steady pace all the way to the end of the game.   Each move is color coded, which enhances the evolving visual motifs of the game as it progresses, but also emphasises the unique role of every move and the way they chain fluidly together.    I can't think of a single game that continued to impress me so much by redefining the core gameplay, again and again, all the way to the end.  The only real complaint I have about this game is that it's over, and I've seen it all.  Other than that, it's one of the best games I've ever played.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												Full of pop culture references, nods to old school gaming, and a great sensor of humour, Guacamelee combines the exploration of the metroid games, and later castlevania games, precision platforming, and beat em up mechanics, similar to final fight and streets of rage.Guacamelee does not have any game overs, or give you any lives, rather, checkpoints are plentiful, but while they are plentiful, they are also well placed.  Later stages in the game demand absolute precision, concentration, and perfection platforming, yet the sense of relief when you pull these parts of with a reward of a checkpoint is fantastic.  While the demands of the platforming parts are in place, you will not ever feel frustrated, as the game encourages you to try to tackle a piece of platforming, and your worse case scenario is your back at the start of the room, and if you run out of health, you return back to the last checkpoint.Combat is plentiful.  Combat is simple, but there is plenty of depth.  Along the course of the game, as you unlock more moves and abilities, you can combine these moves into one gigantic combo.  There are various enemy types, and of course, like any good platformer, some of the enemy placements are quite strategically placed.  When your precision platforming and a flying dragon is trying to knock you off, you instantly remember the older days of platforming on the NES.  Combo attacking, and juggling mid air is encouraged, and the game encourages you to rack up a high combo, rewarding you with extra money.  The potential and depth of the combat system is up to you to discover, but the game does a very good job teaching you the overall basics (One of the side quests involves you linking up different abilities to pull of a combo)The overall pacing of the game is also quite good.  The game never makes you feel like it is a drag.  Just when you feel comfortable, or you come across an area where you need an ability, you usually come across a chozo statue (Yes, right out of metroid) that grants a new ability, which then encourages you to go and further explore.That all said, the game does not take a very long time to complete, and even 100% the story will take just over 10 hours.  Fortunately, there is a hard mode, and there is challenge rooms to keep you interested, while multiple costumes give you specific extra and negative abilities (For example, one suit grants infinity stamina, but you are also unable to regain health) so for people who do like to set their own challenges, there are options here.Overall, if you like humour, metroid style games, or platformers, this is a must buy.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												Guacamelee! Platform, Beat 'em up, explore - rinse and repeat.. But by Lord, it's addictive!!  On occasions it will frustrate you, but overall it's a bloody good button basher!!The music is brilliant, graphics and frame rate are smooth, the story line (rescue the love of your life whilst beating up baddies - THAT'S IT!) is simple, and some of the background imagary, which is usually bright, colourful and typically Mexican (Me Gusta Guava - yes the Me Gusta meme) has made me giggle like mad.Running around there's collectables to be had, coins to be looted (which you can spend on power ups or costumes for your luchador), and a few side missions to give the game some meat. You can choose to run/beat/chicken in either the dead or alive world, and you can alter between Juan and Tostada (Male/Female) at a 'shop' front.Swapping between the alive and dead world opens and closes pathways, and lead off to areas that can give you extra cash, power ups or boosts. Luckily, once you've found a transport system (In the guise of large heads) you can start whizzing about the place. Some of the enimies can be tough and a lot of button bashing is needed, and getting a combo to get certain baddies (and blocks) can be challenging, but still provide an overall fun time.In general, for me at least, this is a brilliant little game, and well worth the money.Now, where's my tortillas?

Posted: January 23, 2014
												You're a tequila farmer who must save the president's daughter from a villain worse than the devil. You die and come back from the dead as a masked luchador (like any normal tequila farmer) ready to save the day. This is a fun platformer with a brawler twist that encourages exploration. You'll notice many references to video games and even get a good laugh or two from this fun and engaging title. After you beat it, you'll have the option to play on hard mode (which is legitimately hard). There's also the inferno: a series of challenges that test your skill at the game.Steamworks is a nice touch and it lets you use custom skins for your character. There's something gratifying about playing as Johnny Bravo. There are many skins and more to come in the workshop. The game also features local co-op. You can play with a buddy if you have a pair of controllers and a tv to hook up to.I got this game on sale at the humble indie store. If you have some extra cash and are looking for a good time, I would definitely recommend this one.

Posted: September 17, 2014
												A wonderful game. The world is built beautifully and the difficulty ramps up in a way that lets you learn quickly. All this while still giving a number of challenges that you may need to try more than a few times. These tend to give you either a "YES, I did it!" reaction or a "Well, I'm glad I don't have to do that again" reaction. However, that is more for completion than for playing through the game itself -- you can get through most of the game without needing to do all the insane side-challenges, but doing them does help hone your skills and make the rest of the game feel easier.There are also a variety of references to a number of pop culture and gaming references throughout the world. They don't get in the way and all seem to have been well integrated into the style of the game. The world of Mexican folklore that Drinkbox was able to portray was pretty cool overall, though it felt somewhat hammy after a while. A very fun and challenging game. I highly recommend it, especially to those who like platformers.Note: I have not yet tried the Co-op.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Just finished this game last night and I have to say I really enjoyed it.  Coming off of Dust: An Elysian Tail before this, both of these games were great MetroidVania-style games, both felt different while not straying too far off the path.- Environment on this game is a little sillier without making it feel stupid- Love the cartoon-like art style  Makes the characters actions and story feel more believable.- Combat system is easy to pick up, and while they can show you many combos with the moves you learn throughout the game, I was able to kind of create my own and play in the action my way, in a sense.- While I don't feel that this game has a lot of replayability, there is quite a bit to do while you are playing it and you can beat the game and go back and finish it if you are up to the challenges.- Some of the platforming is HARD AS HELL... and I loved it!  It is one of things that made me come back for more.- Not to forget, there are little Easter Eggs everywhere, paying homage to great game titles and internet memes.If you like games like Metroid and Castlevania, this is one to pick up, I definitely recommend it.

												This game rocks in just about every individual aspect. The story could be better, but the controls feel great, the art style is fantastic, the action is fun and incredibly fulfilling, the music fits, it's funny, it makes references in the form of signs that you'll walk past twenty times and on the twenty-first time you're like "OH I GET IT", it makes blatantly obvious references that are also hilarious, and you obtain the power to turn into a chicken.That said, the biggest shortcoming of the game is that the moment it starts to really pick up, it's over. Like a Metroid game, you get power-up after power-up right up to the very end of the game, but before the game can fully explore the mechanics of all of your power-ups, you're at the final boss. There are things to collect (many times blocked by pretty challenging obstacles), however, so you can still get your chicken power fix after the game's over.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Guacamelee! Gold Edition is a Metroidvania Mexican styled action platformer. The very first impression of the game is that it looks awesome. A wonderful and colourful atmosphere that reminds me the good old times of Monkey Island. In addition to that, the writing is sharp with a lot of funny dialogues...or to be more precise, the dialogues are mostly monologues since our mexican hero Juan will not say any word during the game.Regarding the combats, I would say that are interesting but they can also end up to be quiet boring. Juan has some standard attacks (punch, kick) but he gains many power ups as he goes deeper and deeper into to the game. My humble opinion is that a medium experienced gamer would need about 10hours to finish the game. But if you want to push your self to the limits you will have to try to unlock as many steam achievents as you can. This is a real challenge, especially if you try to win all gold medals in the El Infierno area (I think I spent two days for this...nightmare).As a conclusion, I would say thay Guacamelee is a great game with humour, fantastic world design and interesting battles. Even if someone is not a lover of 2D platform games I believe that Guacamelee has something for him as well. Finally, if you do not have a CONTROLLER, just do not play the game. The first few hours I tryied it with the keyboard and I can assure you that you will not be able to keep up with steam achievents.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												Guacamelee is a love letter to the Metroidvania genre, in the form of a super-powered romp through the world of Mexican folklore. You are Juan Aguacate, a destitute agave farmer who finds his village under attack by the undead army of Carlos Calaca. The love of his life, who happens to be the daughter of el presidente, has been kidnapped. What is Juan to do? Why, acquire a magic lucha mask and go on a non-linear platforming adventure, get powerups from "choozo" statues, power-slam bad guys, find secrets and navigate rather tricky jumping puzzles, of course. Guacamelee oozes style from beginning to end, with a colorful palette, excellent music and a well-used light/dark world mechanic, requiring the player to frequently switch Juan between the living world and the Mexican land of the dead via portals, often in  mid-jump.  But the game is inconsistent in difficulty. The combat is generally managable and the boss fights are quite simply awesome, but some of the jumping puzzles are incredibly frustrating. In addition, to reach the game's golden ending, it is neccessary to obtain a number of secret items, some of which are located at the end of some fiendishly difficult challenge rooms, many of which, like the trick jump room with its accursed disappearing platforms, I was unable to complete, and this left a bad taste in my mouth. The final boss is also quite difficult, requiring you to demonstrate a mastery over all the abilities you have learned over the course of the game, but when I had finished, I was very satisfied dispite not getting the best ending. I would recommend the game to any fans of Metroidvania, but with caution- it is not a forgiving experience.

All in all, only a few cons come to mind;- it's pretty easy. Only the first boss and final boss really gave me any sort of trouble (apart from all the platforming puzzles I cocked up because I'm a klutz); in fact I think the first boss kicked my♥♥♥♥♥♥even more soundly than the last.- it's pretty short. I beat the main game in just under seven hours, including sidequests, and I'm quite confident I got most of the treasure along the way. That said there's a postgame hard mode and a couple of challenge areas I've not cleared so the replay value's there.- the ending kinda sucks. Really. You beat Calaca and the game just ends, making what never was that satisfying a boss victory fall pretty flat.That said, I still rate this game phenomenal, definitely a must-play.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												It's a fun game, but it gets repetitive and has some crazy difficulty spikes. The game itself plays a bit like a simplified Super Smash Bros., with simple combos that you chain together. You traverse through Mexican-themed environments fighting enemies and gaining powers. Also, while this game advertises itself as a Metroidvania, it is more like a beat-em-up with some exploration. You'll never find yourself lost, and there is (with maybe an exception or two) only one way to reach your goal. There are side quests and small detours, where you collect items or solve puzzles, but they only improve your character's stats and aren't crucial to the main adventure. My recommendation is to buy in a sale if the game seems appealing, but it is far from a masterpiece. Be sure to have a controller, too!

												A really good jump'n'run-like game. The mexican-themed setting, the graphic style and the music make the world of the game feel very alive (or dead, haha) and cool. Some of the jump-puzzles are a bit hard (and not only those needed to get to the extras, some mandatory ones too), but are doable nonetheless. Some (boss-) fights are a bit hard as well, but not really frustrating since the battles are still fair and there are ways to defeat the bosses and enemies, the player just has to figure out. Another plus is that there is an in-game trainer, the combo chicken, where the player gets to learn effective combinations of the various attacks, so that inexperienced players (like me) have an easier time climbing the learning curve of the game.All in all, a good game for everyone who is into jump'n'runns and/or up to a challenge.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Guacamelee is a Metroidvania type game with a focus on combat and very responsive controls. The combat actually has quite a bit of depth to it, reminding me more of the fighting game genre than classical action platformers. A sidequest which is basically a "mini Trial Mode" is also indicative of that. The aesthetics are gorgeous and the game is full of humour and references to other games. Sadly, the game has no voice acting to deliver the funny writing. It's also quite short; while it has tons of treasure hidden all over the game world, completing the game 100% doesn't take too long. It might also be a little too easy for some people; even on hard mode, I had no problem getting through the game in a few hours on my second playthrough. Considering the low price point and the absolute blast I had playing through the game twice basically back to back, I can absolutely recommend this game to anyone, though.

Posted: July 24, 2015
												There is plenty of things that I loved about Guacamelee. It has a very simple and to-the-point combo list. It rarely reuses puzzles and situations. Most puzzles and bosses and challenging but not too much. And most importantly, it doesn't take itself too seriously.But, in a way, it also does take itself seriously. Its challenges are designed to be just manageable, to push you to the limits of your skill. That would have been great if you actually had that level of control. But you don't. The controls are sticky. So, for example, your "D" command becomes "arrow+D", because you were using arrows moments ago, and that changes everything. The developers recommend using a gamepad, but there's no real reason why the keyboard shouldn't work. They simply decided to neglect it.At the same time, combat is based on dissing and receiving stuns. It is entirely possible that the enemies will chain-stun you until you die, and there's nothing you can do to recover.I ragequit this game many times. When it works, it's awesome. But very often it doesn't work, and it often feels like losing wasn't your fault. And that is the biggest fault in a game. A player should never feel like he's being punished for things beyond his control.I know that, technically, it's my fault for not executing the jumps perfectly. However, between the inconsistent difficulty and the imperfect controls, I don't see why I should keep replaying the same section to perfect my jumps to such a degree. The game isn't that addictive or rewarding. What stayed with me from Guacamelee wasn't the good times as much as the ragequits. And for that reason, I don't consider this game a good experience.

												You'll easily get comfortable with the vibrant colors, music, and a sense of accomplishment once you start getting ability upgrades.  Then Guacamelee pulls your sombrero down over your face and beats you into the ground with a sack full of empty tequila bottles.Guacamelee has one level about halfway into the game that is really difficult.  So difficult, I almost gave it a thumbs down, because I would have been really disappointed if I never got past it, since the rest of the game is so good.  I left it alone for several days and then went back to it, finally getting the timing correct to get to the next save point, but my hands looked like gnarled roots when I dropped the controller and begged for mercy.It's a beat-'em-up 2D side-scrolling platformer with a lot of humor and fun combo moves.  Don't try this one without a comfortable controller.  Also, get it on sale, because if you get stuck in the same place I did and never bother trying to finish, you'll be glad you didn't pay full price.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												9/10 Superb!Drinkbox Studios title Guacamlee delivers a knockout punch. Guacamelee delivers exciting gameplay and obstacles that the player must overcome. Throughout the game the player is also able to upgrade Juan’s abilities, which allows the player to explore new areas. The games mechanics also work well and run smoothly so that the experience is not ruined in the least bit. Guacamelee certainly delivers a consistent, and colorful visual design that will draw in players and make the game a joy to explore. Consumers should not expect a simple game however. Guacamelee adds that old school, don’t make a mistake or else formula to its salsa. Some areas give simple challenges, while others are brutally filled with enemies. The player is also able to explore areas in the world of the living, and the world of the dead. Drinkbox Studios has certainly put in a lot of work to make gameplay both interesting and challenging, in a world filled with are influenced by Mexican culture. Guacamelee is a wonderful game, with beautiful designs and challenging gameplay. Though the game was released in 2013, it still gives off a nostalgic feeling of platforming games such as Super Mario World. In fact, there are many cameo appearances from popular games, such as the chozo statue from Super Metroid.

Posted: March 6, 2014
												A fantastic Metroidvania game, due to the lack of ranged combat, all the action is tight, combo based, and skill based.  Skills and abilities are passed out at just the right pace, and nods and winks to old games or cultural memes are everywhere.  Whether it is reminiscing about Super Mario Bros at the end of an action sequence, or catching a glimpse of Castlevania paid homage in a wall display.A welcome feature in this game is drop in couch multiplayer.  After about five minutes of gameplay and basic tutorial, you are able to have a friend join in by grabbing a controller and pressing start.My only complaint is that it seems short.  I believe I'm done the meat of the game for main plotline, nearly at the boss zone, and all I wish is that I had a few more areas to explore, and that is knowing that after saving up X in game cash, I will have one more zone to finish, as well, I still have one last area of the arenas to complete.Overall, a technically and graphically fantastic game.  For 15 dollars, I consider it a worthwhile pickup.  If you find it on sale, it's worth picking up immediately.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												In Guacamelee! you play as the underdog luchador hero Juan, fighting to save the doncella hermosa, El Presidente's daughter from the clasps of Calaca, the king of the dead. You play in a beautiful landscape, with a vibrant, blocky texture to it, and the music combines traditional, mexican mariachi with electro pop, resulting in a really awesome soundtrack.I can easily say that this game gave me the most enjoyment a 2d platformer ever has in the past. With many hours of content, including some really fun and fluid combat which doesn't get old quickly, as well as some very well done megaman-style platforming challenges, this game is definitely worth the money. 10 out of 10.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Guacamelee oozes style and polish from every frame. It's a pitch-perfect Metroidvania (explorable map, powerups to open new paths, etc) with satisfying combo-driven brawler combat that stays both entertaining and challenging from start to finish. The game is also loaded with secrets that provide extra challenge for the truly hardcore, including a gauntlet-style challenge and (in the Infierno bonus content) a series of challenge rooms that test your timing, speed, and combat savvy.The game also supports two-player (local only, I believe) coop, with the second player as the luchadora Tostada. A solo player can also swap to Tostada if they choose, though the game's script will still refer to the player as "Juan."Playing with a controller is strongly recommended.

												This a metroidvania kind of game, but it feels short. As usual, you go through the different areas of a semi connected overworld and get powerups that let you return to places you had to pass up because they were blocked by some kind of obstacle that your new power can handle. It'ss also filled with easter eggs of some familiar AAA and indie games, but they get kind of inane pretty fast. The art and music are kind of stylized for the mexican theme but don't really feel that far from stock. There is plenty of straight up platforming which eventually scales to be pretty difficult, especially in areas hiding secret collectibles that aren't part of the main story. I found it to be of the "remember your combinations "variety instead of anything more exciting though..  Combat is more or less like a brawler, you're generally locked in and have to use optional combos, invulnerable dodges, and abilities (which have ending lag to prevent abuse) It isn't really as smart as a good old capcom game like final fight, and is kind of a step down from similiar hybird games like Elysian Tale and Muramasa as well. If you beat the game you get an optional hard mode, which has no differences bar one.. you get 2-4 hit points. I found this bad in cave story + and I was annoyed with it here as well. Memorization and muscle memory can get you through here as usual, especially with the kind of sluggish game speed. All in all, this is a game that has already been done.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												Summary: Guacamelee! is a platforming game with beat'em up and puzzle elements, which follows the story of an agave farmer named Juan who dons the mask of a luchador to save the world. There is a heavy Mexican influence but also an interestingly large amount of internet-type memes scattered in certain areas of the game. The gameplay is fast, intuitive, and fun with plenty of variety to suit different styles of combat. Although Guaacamelee! is relatively short (2-5 hours roughly), it can be lengthened with features such as co-op play, challenges, and plenty of extras to find throughout each level. The game does get progressively harder and the game is forgiving with the auto-save feature, but it's accessibility and length will make it easy for casual players to finish. Overall I would recommend the game and rate it at a 4/5.Many have compared Guacamelee! to Metroid (also because of some blatant homage in the game ["Choozo statues"]), but I would say it's more like a mash-up of Metroid and Streets of Rage (FInal Fight, any beat'em up). The focus of the combat is to basically chain as many moves into a combo as possible to maximize air time and damage to enemies. Combat is strictly melee-based and is varied with the use of a few mechanics, namely the use of enemy shields and with dimensions. Mid-game, enemies will start to have colored shields surrounding them, the color specifies what type of special attack to use to "break" the shield. Once the shield is down then they are free to be damaged and defeated. The concept of the game's dimensions is by having two worlds, "The Living World" and "The Dead World." This is another concept that will be introduced mid-game, but enemies will belong to either one of the two dimensions and to damage them you will have to go into that dimension to defeat them. So if an enemy is in "The Dead World," you would have to tap a key (R Trigger or Q) to change dimensions in order to beat them into submission. Both concepts will be gradually taught and the learning curve is very short as graphically it's well-depicted.The use of dimensions is another major factor on the platforming aspect of the game. Walls, platforms, and such can be turned "on" and "off" depending on what dimension it is. This creates an interesting platforming mechanic (albeit frustrating at times), where you have to quickly tap to change dimensions when jumping from wall-to-wall, from one hidden platform to the next, or dodging lava by changing dimensions to make harmless water. There is a wide variety of ways this mechanic is utilized and will be the bulk of a wide range of scenarios that are built more like puzzles. Most of puzzles are usually easy to figure, but some will require trial-and-error which the game is more than generous in allowing with little penalty.There is one more mechanic that I feel I should add which is the ability of Juan to change into a chicken mid-game. This opens up a few gameplay mechanics, such as small narrow passages that only the chicken can get into, but as a chicken you're practically defenseless.The graphics are also well-done and crisp, they convey exactly what they need to and makes levels easier to tackle because of how items are presented throughout the game. The style kind of reminds me of the same vector-drawing style of say South Park, it's clean and presents its' own charm and style.The soundtrack is fitting, although I really didn't find myself in awe over the music. It still matches the Mexican, luchador-type theme, but after blazing through the game there was nothing memorable that I heard or just so catchy that I need to search it out. The plot too is in a similar boat, it's present and obviously fits with the game's style, but it's cliched and just like 75% of the other games on the market. Play the hero, save the girl, beat the bad guy into a pulp. There is a bit of a back story, but again, a bit unoriginal. Saying that, I did find all of the "mid-bosses" to be interesting, not so much their stories but their interactions with the protagonist were well-written and brought some humor and charm into the battles.After going through the pros, what can I single out as the biggest con for Guacamelee!? Game length is the easiest element to pick on, if you were to go barebones and blitz through without collecting any powerups or hidden items, you could probably beat the game in 3.5 hours. I didn't mention it, but similar to Megaman, there are pieces of "voodoo heads" and "hearts" scattered in hard-to-reach locations in every level that can be collected and made into an additional stamina bar or increasing the health length. Finding these items can definitely increase your gaming experience by another 4-6 hours, but it will get old and do it very quickly. It's definitley not necessary to beat the game on normal difficulty with any of these additional powerups, but for the very dedicated completionists it is something out there to do. So for the bulk of us, the game will last between 3-6 hours, which is relatively short but..I don't think it seriously hinders the enjoyment of the game. In fact, it may just make the game more accessible for more players.So overall, I found the game to be enjoyable and with the technical accomplishment of the game I would recommend it. It is nowhere near perfect, but it's still a solid game. 4/5

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Well I have had a cracking time playing through this game. It uses the common platform mechanic of getting new special moves as you progress through the game, allowing you to access areas that were inaccessible before. The combat is satisfying and allows you to string some fairly meaty combos together as well as using the main power moves. There are some pretty challenging platform sections that had me pulling my hair out for a bit, but not so hard that it makes you lose interest & give up the challenge.I have never played a game with this kind of art style and atmosphere before. The graphics and the music really draw you in; the whole Mexican Luchador vibe is pulled off perfectly, and has a nice story with some funny touches. I have completed the game, but will go back to it to get those last few secret sections/chests etc. And I think the challenge arenas down in hell will keep me occupied for a while!Would thoroughly recommend this to any one who likes platforming games, with a good bit of combat as well. Brilliant fun.

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Guacamelee! Is an intense platformer where you must fight to save your girlfriend who has been kidnapped, and although the story is bland, the platforming is anything but! With tons of crazy moves like the "goat jump", the "rooster uppercut", and the "Dash DerpDerp", you can be sure that combat will always be interesting, and platforming will be fun. The levels are well designed and the powers you get along the way help you to progress. However, one of my favorite things about this game was the seemingly infinite amount of references. They referenced everything from the Legend of Zelda to terrible internet memes, and everywhere I went I saw even more references that I hadn't seen before! Also, later in the game, you gain a power that allows you to move between the realm of the living and the realm of the dead, when you make this shift, you will see all of the references change to something fitting with the current realm you are in. Some of the references change COMPLETELY! This game was definitely worth a buy. The only bad thing I can think to say about this is that there is no online co-op.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												I want to like Guacamelee. I really do. The Developers did almost everything right. The art style, animations, soundtrack, sound effects, and humor are all top notch. But there are a couple of major problems that hold this game back. The lesser of the two evils is the level design. For the most part, the side puzzles are clever, and the rewards for completing them make them feel worth the effort. However, I can't say the same for the required puzzles. Much of the later half of the game is vertically oriented, and eventually the game seems to degenerate into a very sloppy platformer. There are few things more frustrating than almost making it to the top of a series of very tiny platforms, only to have one of the many enemies that have started chasing you (as there's no room to fight them) hit you, resulting in knockback the likes of which hasn't been seen since the original NES Castlevania games, and send you all the way back down to the bottom.This brings me to the more dire of the game's issues: the controls. As another reviewer mentioned, the game starts off with very tight, responsive, and just generally great controls. But as your move pool increases, you increasingly feel like you're in the game. And by that, I mean that it feels like you're wrestling your controller. There are a pretty decent amount of moves at your disposal by the end of the game, and as which move you use depends on which direction you're moving the control stick, pulling off the right move while moving and trying to dodge can be a hassle.Also, a quick, slightly-spoilery, albeit non-specific complaint about the story:The endings (yes, both of them) are huge letdowns. Especially after the journey to reach them.And now for the good parts:Despite my criticisms, the first half of the game is one of the best metroidvania games I've seen in a long time. The amount of hidden collectibles is incredible, and as I've stated before, the optional puzzles are incredible! And it has the benefit of having something that very, very few PC games seem to include these days: local multiplayer. With steam increasingly pushing Big Picture mode and couch gaming on PCs, Guacamelee is finally giving those of us PC gamers with a social life something we've been longing for for a very long time: a game we can play with friends in the same room (without forcing them to drag their rigs over to our houses). Playing with a friend can reduce the frustration caused by the aforementioned problems, and I'll be honest, it's just plain fun!Overall, despite the control and occasional level design issues, the game is worth playing, especially if it's on sale, and you've got someone to play it with! I might not recommend it at full price, but it's definitly an enjoyable experience.

												The very definition of "short but sweet". This game is a mix of Metroidvania-style progression, beat 'em up combat (with a pretty deep combo system), and some pretty challenging puzzle-platforming. As far as Metroidvania games go, this has to be one of my favourites; the pacing is excellent, combat is very fun, and the platforming is challenging without becoming excessively frustrating. Also, the game has a unique and striking art style, some great humor, and plenty of in-jokes and references to other games.The game only took me around 5 hours to complete (without finding all the secrets), but I loved every minute. Highly recommended.

												You're a tequila farmer who must save the president's daughter from a villain worse than the devil. There's something gratifying about playing as Johnny Bravo. There are many skins and more to come in the workshop. The game also features local co-op. Posted: January 21, 2014
												PROTIP: If you're trying to do the mariachi band quest, you won't actually be able to complete it until you can break blue blocks.A beautiful and funny brawler platformer with metroidvania elements that adds a surprising amount of challenge.The game looks great. The artstyle is very clean and sharp which looks great on an HD tv. The colors are vibrant awesome to look at. Not to mention that every environment has a second variation that also looks cool.The gameplay is quite simple at first. You jump and you fight. It's a formula that's been done before, but this game still does it quite well and is really good at adding variation to gameplay as well as challenge. The platforming is pretty standard, but can become very creative once certain elements are introduced. Once you gain the ability to shift between two worlds, the puzzles start to get pretty interesting. What's more is that the world shifting becomes a part of the combat too. Certain enemies will only be able to be hit in certain worlds, which can really put you under some pressure. You also fight different kinds of enemies that need to be disarmed with a spefic attack before you can actually hurt them. There's a lot of good enemy variation. You're also given the ability to turn into a chicken which lets you explore and also lets you skip past some enemies if you don't feel like fighting every one.There are also sidequests and an area where you can do challenges that teach you combos. They also start off easy but quickly ramp up and can be difficult if you're unfamiliar with fighting games. But those parts are optional and just get you money.If there are any criticisms I have of this game, they have to do with co-op. Now don't get me wrong the local co-op in this game is quite fun! Beating up bad guys together is great. But a lot of the puzzle platforming becomes a bit problematic when you have two people. Specifically shifting between worlds. Both players can shift worlds freely, but some of the platforming will require you to have specific timing. This can really be a problem because, unless you and your partner are perfectly synced with your jumping timing, you'll most likely shift worlds at a bad time, causing one person to get caught in a wall, which will automatically force a shift back to the world you were in, and make you both mess up. Thankfully the game is forgiving and it has a work around for things like this. At any time, either player can become a bubble by pressing a button. This allows them to move freely about the screen, taking no damage and dealing none, until the other player punches the bubble and frees them. This mechanic is also used when one person dies in combat, they come back as a bubble. This definitely resolves a lot of issues with the platforming, but it kinda stinks when one of you has to stop playing so that you can both make progress. It shows that the game was designed with one player in mind. Again, this is only a minor complaint, playing co-op was still lots of fun.A great game, so glad it came to Steam.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												This is my first review and was made purely to help me get used to writing more, please don't judge it too harshlyI didn’t think much of Guacamelee before I played it, but the roughly 5 hour experience was very satisfying. It begins like any typical videogame hero story, a weak hero goes about his day doing menial tasks that conveniently teach the player how to interact with the world when suddenly, the villain appears taking the love interest with him. While very cliche, it is still done well and throws in fairly interesting characters and amusing twists to fit the theme.  The traditional Mexican art style is an interesting new take that helps articulate the theme of the world, which is paired with a very catchy mix of Mexican instruments and techno. My only real complaint lies in the default female luchador design, whose extremely large chest is barely covered by a long white cloth wrapped around her chest. Then from her waist comes a long transparent skirt that might as well not be there. However there is an alternate costume that features her in more reasonable dress, though it must be bought ingame. There is also a reasonably large skin modding community for the pc.At first glance, Guacamelee’s combat may seem button mashy, but that tactic will only get you past the first quarter of the game before It is harshly punished. Most enemies either actively dodge about, dig into the ground to avoid harm, or show no reaction to blows at all until death. The only way to reliably produce a combo with these enemy types is to keep them airborne for as long as possible which requires very careful timing. This is where most of the game’s challenge comes from as the puzzles are usually relatively simple and mostly only require figuring out with what timing to use which ability. The boss fights are much like these puzzle areas, usually actively punishing use of the same tactics that would be used on enemy groups. There are also plenty of powerups to find and purchase consisting of power grapples, health and stamina upgrades, and costumes. The power grapples are basically variants of the throws that either do focus damage, do damage around you, or simply do more damage to the enemies that are hit.Guacamelee is a solid Metroid-vania with wonderful art and music that very much deserves your attention.

Posted: May 22, 2014
												A satisfying game. Guacamelee! is not a long game by any means, it took me about 4 or 5 hours to get to the ending on normal difficulty the first time through, collecting about 50% of everything. I feel like I haven't really seen everything there is to see quite yet. I'd suspect that finding everything would take a lot longer, and that the additional challenges found in Gold Edition will make it last longer. Combat feels right, and is much deeper than it initially feels. The game is pretty unforgiving and difficult, especially near the end, so old-school gamers can enjoy that. If you're up the the challenge, Guacamelee! is a great game, filled with dozens of references to other games in an environment that's dripping with personality. It should be noted as well that the game features local co-op. It's a lot of fun to play with the right friend, but some of the platforming sections feel as though they were designed with a single person in mind and can be difficult to pass with a second player. However, playing alone you'll wish you had a second set of fists against some of the tougher battles. It's all possible alone or with a friend. It's better with someone else overall. Try it both ways.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												Challenging platformer.Guacamalee is a 'Metroid-styled, 2D- platformer developed by DrinkBox Studios. The plot of the game revolves around a farmer named Juan trying to to rescue the president's daughter from the clutches Carlos (the skeleton) who is goiing to sacrafice her in order to rule the world. In order to do so, Juan chases Carlos and defeats his lackies along the way.Soundtrack is fantastic, giving off a mexican feel and draws you into the unique world. There is no voice acting with character dialogue through text. The sound effects for attacks are also good.The graphics suit the game well. the colours are  vibrant and  not distracting, and do a good  job at instilling the mexican atmosphere in the game. Furthermore,  the characters and stages all have a mexican styled design to them which helps invoke the mexican atmosphere in the game.Gameplay revolves around platforming and combat. The platforming in in this game varies between simple to challenging. Some platforms only require a few moves to get to such as simply jumping on them, while more challenging ones require precisely timed executions in order to reach. For the challenging platforming areas, it is difficult to get the precise key inputs through the keyboard as it can only detect a limited number of inputs at a time. I was forced to play with a 360 controller which made the experience more fluid and less frustrating. In combat you face a wide variety of foes including skeletons, dragons and  giants which either have melee or ranged attacks. The aim is mainly to unleash as many combos on them as possible to prevent them from attacking you. You have a varity of attacks which you can used to defeat your foes or to help reach platforms from side smash, uppercut and throws. You unlock more moves as you progress through the story. Furthermore, you can upgrade you character in variety of ways including increasing health, damage and spawn delay (by spending money). Furthermore, you can play the game via local co-op with a friend.There are alot of references to other videogames such as nintendo characters Mario and Link (with mexican vibes to them). Furthermore, there are secrets hidden withen each area which allows you to unlock new costumes for your character. The different costumes each have a unique trait, such as increasing health/damage, which you can use to change how you tackle the combat. Plenty of other secrets lie in the game including secret stage which you can unlock by collecting enough money.I highly recommend this game to people you love unique and challenging platformers.
